story:
Click here to be redirected to our final run campaign for the Spiral Knights

 

Πλήρης αναλυτική μετάφραση στα Ελληνικά πατώντας εδώ

What is Free and Real and the Telaithrion Project?

The Telaithrion Project’s mission is to create the first, much needed, eco-community model in Greece that will work as a school of self-sufficiency and an exemplar model of sustainability, with healthy and harmonic living conditions with respect to human values and the ecosystem,  renewable sources of energy, clean and efficient means of transportation, continuous research and education on all relevant topics and technologies, made available equally to all.

The project is being created in Evia island for almost 7 years now, with more than 25000 visitors from every corner of the world and a weekly outreach of more than 120000 people! Visit our facebook page by clicking here, to get all the insight from the course of events, from the very first day until now, and feast your eyes on the countless photo albums depicting, your own remarkable and priceless help for everything that is being achieved. 

More information on the subjects that we research, our goals, our collaborations and everything that has to do with Free & Real can be found @ Telaithrion.freeandreal.org (in 6 languages and counting) and @FreeandReal.org (Greek and English version available).

Also don't forget to check out all the videos in the "Gallery Section" or by clicking here

With this campaign, and with your invaluable support, we aim to raise the project to the next level of cooperation and co-creation!

With this campaign we will continue raising the necessary funds to complete new infrastructure that is needed to make the Spiral Knights Eco-Fest 2017 (5 to 10 of September) an even greater event, with sustainability as our main compass and collaboration and co-creation our main goals.

Check out 1000 photos from last years Spiral Knights

What We Need & What You Get

Getting into more detail:

Last years Spiral Knights Festival was something that we were cooking in our brains for many years now and it really, really paid off. We had a magnificent off-grid celebration of sustainability and it was an amazing way to bring together people and projects from Greece and the world, to co-create and achieve beautiful realizations together. It was a truly unique experience but we realized 4 days are not enough.. So this year we go for 6! Join Us!

So we double down on everything and again this year during the event there will be live music, theater and dance performances, more enhanced practical workshops (eco-building, cooking, permaculture and more) and part from the daily seminars (yoga, tai-chi, thai-massage, acrobatics, capoeira, chi kung and more), all the teacher and teams will run their individual "Summer Camps" @ the Spiral Knights Eco-Fest. This means you can book your spot and do your favorite seminar 2 times per day with food and camping included and also be part of an amazing festival!

Full Info for the Summer Camps on the links bellow

  • Acrobatics Camp @ Spiral Knights Eco-Fest 2017 (155 Euros right now)
  • Healing Camp @ Spiral Knights Eco-Fest 2017 (149 Euros right now)
  • Sound & Self Healing Camp @ Spiral Knights Eco-Fest 2017 (149 Euros right now)
  • Yoga & Thai Massage Camp @ Spiral Knights Eco-Fest 2017 (149 Euros right now)
  • Yoga & Tantra Camp @ Spiral Knights Eco-Fest 2017 (149 Euros right now)

All kids under 12 get free entrance.

Also note the campaign pricing is in Dollars so its much less in Euros!

Surprise update! Two Solar Bluetooth Speakers System for two lucky Knights!

5 pairs of FreeandReal Sunglasses for 5 lucky winners from Anastasiadis Optica Stores

 

This campaign it is connected with the designing and building of a mobile off-grid trailer solar/battery system that will be able to support all the energy needs of our off grid efforts! We are in the process of designing this off-grid monster, with the valuable help of our friends from SEYN  as also other off grid systems that will be used in the Spiral Knights and will be build during our Energy Mastercourse Vol II workshop in June.

Participations, Live acts and performers will be announced during the summer and through this campaign. Trust us the Line Up is on fire!!!

BIOΣ 5 Five Cereal Beer Official Beer of the Spiral Knights Eco-Fest 2017

Participations so far..

Innerstate Live PA & DJ Set | Transform Evia | Martian Arts Live PA & DJ Set | The Pangea | DJ MAJO | ENA Assembly | Evi Sidiropoulou DJ Set | Maria Papidaki DJ Set | Basma Kamal | Jokasti & Nek B2B DJ Set | Nina Adamopoulou | Birth Story | Nature Play | Slow Motion Live | (F)orest School | SEYN |

Many new different stages and event domes will be set-up and there will be in site camping for the participators . Also a brand new food-court with amazing vegan food, with recipes from all over the globe, and many other constructions and surprises will be set up all over the place. A kid's area and playground will be also there and also many games for young and not so young people will be prepared.

Basically through this campaign we give you the chance to reserve your camping spot on the mountain site. We will be opening new perks with this specific focus all the way to the festival.

The sooner you get your perk the less you will contribute!

This event will be a co-creation and everyone will participate in its realization one way or another. Everyone will be personally responsible for the cleanness and safety of the space and the surrounding forest. Recycling, up-cycling and composting will be as always a must!

Stay tuned and check back periodically for news and updates!

Setting up this festival will give us the chance to create the infrastructure for future events in and around the Telaithrion Project's site. Be part of it!

Spiral Knights Festival 2017

Do you imagine an international festival bringing people from all over Greece and the world to celebrate sustainability in all its aspects and forms? Waking up on a mountain site with a dreamy ocean view, after that participating in inspiring workshops, eating amazing food and dancing (under a late summer full moon) inside a geodesic dome full of lights, dance and laughter?... We had imagined that and did it too! But last year was just the beginning,now it’s time for the second one, and probably it’s the time for you to join us!

Last year’s festival was the fruit of intensive 2 and half month labour done by an international team of young creative people and the years of the collective experience and knowledge of the people that are co-creating and supporting the ‘’Telethrion Project’’, Free and Real’s baby.

Served in a nutshell,all this knowledge will perform around us once again, through possibly ‘’life changing’’ workshops, talks and presentations happening on the many different stages of the Spiral Knights grounds

Other Ways You Take Be Part 

If you are not in a position to help by participating in the event, don't worry, there are many ways to help us achieve not only this goal, but also the project as a whole.

  • Post this campaign again and again, on your favorite social media (facebook, twitter, youtube, etc).
  • Invite your friends to like our FB Page (https://www.facebook.com/FreeandReal)
  • Send an e-mail to your friends and family letting them know about us.
  • Volunteer for the event! We will need a lot of help setting all this up!

If you are part of a business or company, or you own a business or company, make a donation through your company and see the name of it display among all the other contributors to all our media outlets.  Also you can offer us materials that we so much need to set up the festival! Contact us for more details

  • Send us an e-mail letting us know what else you can offer (skills, tools, know-how, ideas etc)
  • Come visit us, work with us and lend us your hands to create a more sustainable future!

Thank you all for sharing and supporting!!!

story:
Short Summary

 

 

 

 

Background

Everyone's Climbing Tree (ECT) is a not-for-profit company and family run community arts centre  in Wood Green, North London. ECT was established by the Sabbagh family after the death of local community figure, and their father and husband Mustapha Sabbagh in 2010. Since then we have been curating community workshops and events for people of all ages and backgrounds.

Through alternative teaching techniques and a strong ethos of communal learning we have developed a reputation for youth engagement. Supported by Youth Music and Arts Council England our programme of West African percussion, often working with young people excluded from mainstream education, has had a massive impact. Over the past seven years we have assisted many young people, helping them grow into the resilient and positive young adults they are today.

At a time when global shifts dominate our thoughts and the rapid developments in London are literally changing the shape of our horizons, we at Everyone's Climbing Tree need your help to grow. 

Please help us raise £10,000 so we can expand the opportunities for young people, creative practitioners and our local community to affordable access to the arts and self development.  

We aim to combine start up entrepreneurial talent and youth mentoring to create an organic localised model that has the ability to be self funded. Renovating these spaces will enable ECT to be a self reliant and robust organisation with the ability to plan steadily into the future.

What We Need 

Concrete Foundations (£2000) The outdoor floor needs to be sturdy for dancing on!

Electricity Line (£2000) We are tripping the fusebox. One band got shut down half way through their gig, help us, we need a second electric line!

Electric Metres (£750) More spaces means more creatives, so we need to measure our electricity usage with precision.

Soundproofing (£2250) More people means more sound, we don't want to disturb other people's learning or inhibit their creativity.

Live Room/Vocal Booth (£1000) Internal sound proofed windows can make a cupboard into a vocal booth, a rehearsal space into a live recording room and a studio into a recording control room.

Insulation (£1250) Summer is fine, but winter can be freezing in these old wooden railway buildings!

Outdoor Toilets (£750) More people are joining the tribe but we currently only have one toilet on site!

What You Get

The Sabbagh family that founded ECT continue the ethos of North African family values with a back bone of African culture and music. All of our Perks are named after tribes or notable historic  figures from Africa. Come join us and become a part of the tribe with a combination of badges, posters, T-shirts, introductory workshops and the chance to have your name added to our story with your name on our shop front Graffiti mural.

We are very enthusiastic about our campaign but we also know that you always need a Plan B. So if we do not reach our entire goal we will fix the basic essentials such as toilets, electricity and insulation. As always we will continue to work creatively on a shoe string and raise funds to do the things we dream of for our local area and Everyone's Climbing Tree. On the other hand if we raise more than intended we will put the money into recording a second cross-cultural album. Currently working titles are "Dakar 2 London II" or "London 2 Dakar" let us know if you have any suggestions!

The Impact

The ECT team although small and family based are deeply intuitive problem solvers, thinking outside the box, with an abundance of creativity. As residents of the Borough of Haringey for over 30 years we quietly continue to develop and deliver projects that have had a massive impact on the lives of local people.  If you look back at what we have achieved so far imagine what we can do in the future. "Roots 2 Fruits".

Dakar 2 London A Cross-Cultural 10 Track Album a project that started when ECT musical Director Skanda Sabbagh travelled to Dakar in 2014. ECT in collaboration with master drummer Khalifa Conte recorded 8 tracks in Senegal and 2 Tracks in the UK with our youth drummers. The album was released in December 2016. 

 

AP and Beyond The community Art-Trail has run for four consecutive years curated by ECT Artistic Director Sonya Sabbagh. Local artists, musicians and creatives in the Alexandra Palace area open their doors so that the general public can see and hear their work. With a map of 40+ open houses and events, some participants had so many people attend there was not enough space in their home to accommodate them all. http://www.apandbeyond.co.uk

Tree Top Drumming Funded by Youth Music since 2013 Tree Top Drumming is an initiative designed and delivered by ECT musical director Skanda Sabbagh. Working with challenging young people excluded from mainstream education, Skanda and the team teach African drumming to  over 100 students in 5 different locations on a weekly basis.

Gidde Bille Funded by Arts Council England this project was created by music leaders Khalifa Conte and Skanda Sabbagh. Noticing that young people wanted to learn more advanced African drumming techniques we decided to invite them to take part in sessions on our home turf. This has since developed into a 15 strong ensemble of Teenage African Drummers who perform regularly throughout the capital.

Other Ways You Can Help

Thank you for taking the time to read through our campaign we are very grateful for your time. Although we are trying to raise money for ECT we are also trying to raise awareness of our cause and the work we are doing. Even if you cannot afford to donate please share our campaign with friends, family and colleagues!

We love to make the big noise-hope you do too!!!

Our Crowd Funding campaign launches at our SUNDAY FUNDAY event on the 30th of April 2017. If you were not able to make it you will still be in the loop as we will be posting a video of the event shortly afterwards.

Roots 2 Fruits

story:
About us

Creating Commons CF is a festival of audiovisual media, inspired by – and basically actualizing – the Commons and Social, Solidarity and Collaborative Ecomony, that will take place in October, 2018.

Why CCCF?

The aim of CCCF is to bring together people of technical knowledge and artistic view with people having experiences and stories to share on issues of the Commons and Social, Solidarity and Collaborative Economy, with the purpose of grassroots production of open audiovisual works, collective or individual.

Why we need this crowdfunding?

CCCF is a self-organized event, without submission fees, tickets, or any other funding.

We need your help to cover organizing expenses, such as equipment, travel and accommodation of guests for the events during the festival, and so on.

Why support CCCF 2018?

CCCF is the first cinematography festival in Athens focused on the Commons.

We need your support to cover expenses, such as: equipment for video display installations, audio systems, internet connection and networking, travel, food and accommodation expenses for guests.

The Festival won't run for just once though. We've already organized self-education courses on video production, and plan to do much more in the coming years!

Our plans include a platform of exchange of video material under Creative Commons

story:
Who We Are

We are students in the Humber Arts Administration and Cultural Management graduate certificate program. For our end of year project, we have organized an event for newcomers to Canada through storytelling, performances and art called 'Stroke of Luck.'

What We Want to Achieve 

Inspired by Akshata Naik's 'Bloody Boats' art installation, guests will have the opportunity to write down their stories on paper to fold into an origami boat, placing their journey into the new installation with other newcomers.

There will be performances by local and international musicians and artists. 

We hope to highlight and celebrate the efforts and stories immigrants have experienced during their move to Canada, while creating a sense of community for newcomers. We think it is important to create welcoming and safe spaces for immigrants and newcomers to connect and express themselves.

With your donation, you will be supporting the creation of a welcoming environment for newcomers to Canada. 

What We Need 

We are looking to raise $500 to help us pay for artists and other logistics that will help shape and complete our event.

The profits we make from 'Stroke of Luck' will be going to Ahmed Moneka's efforts to be reunited with his family in Canada who are currently waiting in Turkey after leaving Iraq.

story:
About us:
FreeCon is Tallahassee's premier anime convention, hosted annually by the Japanese Animation Club at Florida State University. We are a free-entry convention for anime, gaming, comics, and many other kinds of popular media enthusiasts. FreeCon's staff is comprised entirely of students and volunteers that work together throughout the year to bring this convention into fruition. Since we are free for everyone to attend, we could use all the support we can get! We would greatly appreciate every bit we receive to help us with our organizing, such as for guests and prizes.

Contact us at: fsu.freecon@gmail.com

Check us out at: Our Website | Facebook | Twitter | Tumblr | Instagram | Reddit | Twitch | YouTube | Ko-fi

What FreeCon has to offer:

FreeCon brings to the Tallahassee community and beyond, a free convention experience! Though small, with FreeCon we can give an experience similar to most conventions to those who wouldn't necessarily be able to spend the money or travel with the typical costs most conventions require to attend. It is our organization's mission to bring people together through common interests and hobbies such as anime, video-games, or Japanese pop culture. We believe this will help foster goodwill and lasting friendships in our community. We will have a variety of activities and events such as a Cosplay Contest, Maid Café, Video Game Room, Panels, Vendors' Hall, Artist Alley, Drawing Contest, and more! Of course, we'll gladly in return give back to those who've supported us with Indiegogo rewards created by our beloved Art Team. 
Due to COVID-19 concerns, we decided to make the convention online this year. We at FreeCon still intend to do our best to provide a fun convention experience even virtually! We still intend to have various free-to-attend convention activities, including contests, tournaments, panels, virtual artist alley, and more!

Your contribution & Indiegogo rewards:

Based on your contribution to our campaign, you're eligible for the following rewards:

Note: This year all physical rewards will be shipped, so an additional shipping fee will be charged.

Buttons: Designed around this year's theme and mascots, with our Art Team's individual styles. Up to 8 different buttons can be received. Stay tuned for updates on the available buttons!

Stickers: Designed around this year's theme and mascots, with our Art Team's individual styles. Up to 8 different stickers can be received. 

Commissions: A digital print of artwork customized to your request, created by our beloved Art team. See the "Commissions" section below for more details. 

FreeCon 17 T-Shirt: Receive a specially designed shirt by our beloved Art Team. They won't be reproduced as we change our theme each year, so we'll hold onto one just for you for supporting us! Adult sizes. 

Indiegogo Backer Role on Discord: Feel extra special showing off that you are a supporter of the convention with an Indiegogo Backer role on our convention Discord server!

Prints: High quality prints of official FreeCon artwork. You may request to have any of the prints signed by their artist on our Art Team. Stay tuned for updates on the available prints!

Name on Website: As a special thanks for your contribution, your name will be included on the affiliates page on our website to let everyone know how spectacular you are for supporting us!

Name in Opening Ceremony: During the opening ceremony, we will mention you as one of our top contributors with our most thankful voices to the audience. 

*Special Top Tier reward*: TBA. Stay tuned for the reveal!

Commissions:
There are different levels of commissions based on your contribution, as listed below. You can request the artist responsible, character, and pose on all the commission levels. For the top level of commission, S-level, you can also request the background. The artists on our Art Team that will take care of commissions will be: Vivian Murphy (all levels), Ali Rogers (C-A levels), Jessica Soderman (all levels), Haileigh Walton (C Level only). Please keep in mind if the artist you requested has a significant workload or there is a sudden change, the artist you requested to be responsible for your commission may change. 

Level C Commission: A bust with no color or in monochrome of one character of your choosing. Or alternatively a "chibi" version of one character of your choosing. 

Level B Commission: A bust with color or alternatively a full-body commission of one character of your choosing with no color or in monochrome. 

Level A Commission: A full-body, full-color commission of one character of your choosing.

Level S Commission: A full-body commission of one character of your choosing with a background, in full color. 

Artists' samples of all their levels of commissions are available in the gallery at the top that you may go through for reference.

For your convenience, here are examples of each commission level:

FreeCon 17 Heads of Staff

Executive & Convention Head

Sophia Vo

Assistant Convention Heads

Thomas Darby & Vivian Murphy

Maid Café Heads

Lauren Boylan, Ali Rogers, & Matthew Schaffer

story:
Dorset Chamber Music Residency

Dorset Chamber Music Residency (DCMR) is a community-based chamber music residency that will have its inaugural season in Dorset, VT this summer (June 25-July 2nd). We will present five public performances including a storytelling program for kids, an outdoor performance and neighborhood potluck, and a concert at the town church featuring Maurice Ravel’s Introduction and Allegro for all seven DCMR musicians.

DCMR receives support from the New England Conservatory Entrepreneurial Musicianship Department, and the Dorset community, which opened its doors for the DCMR fundraising concert in March and for a concert by the flute/harp duo kairos in July 2016.

 

The DCMR Team

  • KASA String Quartet: Andy Liang and Aaron Schwartz, violins; Stephanie Price-Wong, viola; and Kyle Price, cello
  • Amalie Wyrick-Flax, clarinet
  • kairos: Fanya Wyrick-Flax, flute; and Alix Raspe, harp (DCMR co-directors)
  • Masa Jankovic, everything lights and camera
  • Mikaela Bloomberg, chef extraordinaire
  • Oktaven audiO Team: Ryan Streber and Jessica Slaven, our fabulous audio engineers
  • Dizzy and Flora, our loving Cockapoo dog cheerleaders!

 

Schedule of Events

Sunday 6/25 at 10am: Church service performance at the United Church of Dorset - kairos

Wednesday 6/28 at 7pm: Performance at Hathaway House, generously sponsored and hosted by Dorset resident Terri Hathaway - All DCMR musicians!

Friday 6/30 at 4pm: Outdoor concert and community potluck outside the Dorset Colony House - All DCMR musicians!

Saturday 7/1 at 3pm: Musical Storytelling Program for children of all ages at the Dorset Library - kairos

Sunday 7/2 at 4pm: Performance at United Church of Dorset - All DCMR musicians!

 

How YOU can help:

We need your help to reach our fundraising goal! Your support towards our $8,000 goal goes directly towards:

  • Video/Audio fees: Masa Jankovic and Oktaven Audio
  • Artist fees including housing and hospitality
  • Advertising costs
  • Event/food expenses
  • Equipment rental

Make a donation and receive perks, including: special VIP access to secret video footage, custom Spotify playlists, posters, tickets to concerts, concert recordings, dinner for two with musicians, house concerts, and more!

 

Other ways you can help 

  • Share this campaign with your friends!
  • Visit our website for more info
  • Like us on Facebook
  • Have an idea for another way you can be involved? Email us at dorsetchambermusicresidency@gmail.com!

We're so excited about this project, and we can't wait to see you in Dorset, VT this summer!

Love,

Fanny Wyrick-Flax and Alix Raspé

story:
Hey!

We are an open group of people that came together in Barcelona, coming from all over the world and sharing the same love and passion for skateboarding.
Everyone involved and getting involved is bringing its own skills and experience (either in construction, communication, funding or art support) but, most of all, its motivation to build/learn how to build all together with concrete.

We spent the last four months collecting tools, digging the all place with shovels, recycling all the plywoods and rebars we could to low the budget and give a use to society's waste to prepare what seems to be around 80m2 hole in the wood that needs to be filled with concrete. 
We even have been able to pour the first four transitions of the big section with money we raised in a party, invest ourselves and thanks to the help of various collaborators  and builders, from both local and international community. 

Further than the bowl we're building, this project is also meant to get people that loves skateboarding to create together, to think, design, fund, build and, obviously, skate it together. 
Skateboarding came so far and is what it is now since people that skate and share the same passion for skateboarding developed it and made it what we know.
That's why, at a moment and in a city where big companies and people that doesn't care about skateboarding are taking over its industry and its spirit along with it, it makes sense to keep that spirit alive having people that truly loves skateboarding working together, spending their time and energy to create for that love, for free and for everyone to share that passion. 
That's also why we didn't want to get any brand or official institution involved in the funding of the project and choose to call the skate community to help us on that one...  So we ask you to bring a little contribution, if you can and are keen to do it, either with buildings materials or some cash to pay for the materials to finish it.
As we already have a bunch of rebar and plywood is easy to recycle, money will go straight into concrete, aggregates and sand. So that we should be able to complete the all project with around 1500€. But we're still working on others events not to run short on money... 
In case we would get some extra money from the donations, we will use it to improve the designs and extend the bowl, so as to support the D.I.Y. project "Caribu" leaded by some builders of our team in Mataro so they can keep building there too!
Anyway we made an important point to keep the budget clear and public so that everyone that is contributing can see what's coming in and where it goes. 
If some of you can't contribute with money, material or working strenght, you can still support by spreading the word and sharing this with your buddies on social network so we can get more support! 

All the similar project worlwide, either leaded by bigger organization such as « Make Life Skate Life » or « Skate-Aid » or locals communities (2er in Hannover, The Beast in Zurich or Burnside in the US) already showed that these dreams come true when a group of people get together pushed by the all community, so lets make it happen again and again !

For the love of skateboarding and independent project, we thank you for your attention and support, and hope we can bring this space to life and share it with all of you! 

(P.S: If you can ship us the money without using the platform please consider that option so we can actually receive all your contribution tax-free, also because the money of the platform will arrive in 45days and we will have to pay in advance... thanks for understanding)

story:
ENGLISH, 日本語, ESPAÑOL

ENGLISH

What is Kota-Kunde

Kota-Kunde is a product of the unrivaled master of the Afro-Peruvian culture, Maestro Lalo Izquierdo and his selected leaders of the next generation. I think his work is an important project of cultural succession to the next generation. He once said to me, “I work with you, not with that company anymore. So, if you are gone, no one remains.” The master of soul chose to trust me very much saying finally “this project would go only with you.”  

The project I need to revive with your support is a three-part mini-documentary, a story about afro peruvian culture, and a show. Tragedy for this perfect project of our dreams happened 4 years ago.  It was too late to cancel a film shoot that was already coordinated through the company, paid in full by me, and it has remained my private debt.  We were scammed by the former producer who was prosecuted but not facing justice to this day.   

All to inherit the traditional culture​

Today my project needs me in every way. I have to revive this project.  Unfortunately in Peru there is almost no system for inheriting traditional culture and therefore, everything is changing and flowing in the commercial direction. The creators and sustainers of the Afro-Peruvian culture are lamenting this situation. I am very concerned that this wonderful true tradition could face extinction.  All the members are very excited to restart. It is full of very positive energy. The only thing we need is the funds. Afro-Peruvian music has some typical rhythms. The Kota-Kunde 1 of the Zapateo project was asleep in 2015 and the Kota-Kunde 2 of Festejo, plans to shoot new this year.  These are two rhythm documentaries that need funding to reach their true potential, an opportunity that is critical at the cusp of this historical turning point. This project aims to pass on the history and culture of Afro-Peruvian through music and dance. We are confident as it has already received offers for exhibitions from public schools and educational institutions. Peruvian children are divided by a huge wage gap. The children playing soccer on the roadside often cannot afford cleats, yet they can have dreams of becoming world-class soccer players.  Just like a successful soccer player is regarded as a role model for children across many socioeconomic classes, Kota-Kunde can also be a model for our children.  It is fun to dance with the rhythm of Cajon without spending a lot of money, yielding a chance to dream and express.  I think such cultural foundation leads us to both recognize and strengthen its identity. We want all to inherit the traditional culture, give dreams, and cultivate the foundation of the power to live through.

Profile of producer

I was born in Tokyo and had a fortunate home environment where I could always listen to Western music. I started playing musical instruments at the age of three and became familiar with Western pop music as well. I became fond of Bossa Nova, Samba, Funk, Reggae, Jazz, Blues, Salsa, and all kinds of music. I was particularly fascinated by Latin music.  This led me to desire a life in South America. I visited Peru for the first time in 1999 and was fascinated by the energy of land and people. My home is now in Peru. Here I encountered Afro-Peruvian music and realized that all of my favorite music was of African roots.

In this dream land of mine my life goes on in unexpected ways.  While I enjoyed this unique endeavor, I had to go through divorce in 2011. I endured the divorce with my two daughters whilst also developing and fighting cancer. Needless to say I had a hard time raising two young daughters and surviving in a foreign land.   Local Peruvian friends and Afro-Peruvian friends helped feed energy to me and my family through their Peruvian music.  It was my confirmation; the world of Afro-Peruvian music and dance had been my life.  I have been with these soulful musical people and have been interacting with them like true families.

My Passion

My passion has extended and in 2015, a Peruvian woman introduced by a musician offered me a position as a music director.   Excitingly, I became a partner of the company.  I passionately, in the name of the art and of spreading Peruvian art to the world started to produce some groups that I selected a fusion of Peruvian traditional and contemporary music. However, the woman has teamed up with a famous French television director and took the precious money which had been funded to me from many heartfelt and vulnerable people. I still do not want to give up. 

For next generation

I want to make this culture known not only in Peru, but also across the world. I see great power in the power and value of this cultural tradition and I hope others can share in that vision.  Thank you for financing Kota-Kunde, and believing in me and my fellow Afro-Peruvian musicians and feeding a dream to revive dormant but lively soulful cultures for the  next generation.  

Special Thanks to 

Last but not least, I give a mention of Yuko N. Taylor, a classmate who cooperated with this project who has seen the fusion of African culture and modern culture in the southern part of North America through the eyes of an artist and the eyes of a producer. 

日本語

コタクンデとは？

文化継承・教育プロジェクト。 アフロペルービアンの歴史と伝統文化を、音楽やダンスを通して、広く深く次世代に継承していく、また世界に広めていくためのプロジェクト。コタクンデ（美しい心の意味）は、アフロペルービアン文化の世界では知らない人はいない巨匠、ラロ・イスキエルドと彼の選んだ次世代のリーダーたちのユニットです。このプロジェクトはミニドキュメンタリー、巨匠のアフロペルービアン文化の話（質問・回答形式）、ショーの３部構成です。教育機関や文化イベントに提供していきます。 アフロペルービアン音楽には、大きく分けると４つの典型的なリズムがありますが、そのうちの２つ、サパテオ（タップダンス）のコタクンデ１、フェステホのコタクンデ２、今年はまずはこの２つにフォーカスします。

なぜ資金が必要か

アフロペルービアンの音楽やダンスは、パーティーやイベントなどには必ず使われ、ペルー全国の人が知っています。ただそれは、商業的なものに形を変えてしまっており、本来のものとかけ離れていっています。残念ながら、ペルーには芸術的な伝統文化を継承するシステムが、ほぼ存在しません。アフロペルー文化の巨匠たちは2世の世代にあたり、すでに高齢です。このままでは、この伝統文化は正しく継承できず、絶えてしまいます。前出の２つのテーマのミニドキュメンタリー完成のための資金が必要です。

お礼のアイテム（リターン）

プロジェクトの目的に合わせて、みなさまに知っていただき、楽しんでいただけるあるいは学んでいただけるお礼を中心にご用意しています。特に一般の方に馴染みやすいのは、・Jarana Criolla 15$(プライベートライブビデオ)　・Video Cajon Lesson with musica 50$（カホンレクチャーを含むライブビデオ）だと思います。カホンを習得したい方には、レッスンビデオやバーチャルレッスンがあります。また、文化イベント主催者の方向けリターンもございます。すべて各々をクリックすると、日本語での詳細説明が見られます。また、BACK ITをクリックすると、US＄で自由に金額を設定していただける募金もございます。

伝統文化の継承

残念ながら、ペルーでは伝統文化を継承していくというシステムや考え方がほとんどなく、すべて形を変えて商業的な方向に流れてしまっています。この文化の巨匠たちもその状況を大変嘆いており、私もこの素晴らしい伝統が違った形でしか世に出ていないことを大変残念に思っています。資金面の問題で、しばらく休眠状態でしたが、巨匠たち（２世）が近年次々にこの世を去り、このままでは本当にこの文化が立ち消えてしまうので、一念発起し再開しました。メンバー（3世、4世）も再スタートに向けて、ポジティブなエネルギーでいっぱいです。

アイデンティティと子供達の夢

貧富の差が激しいペルーの子供たち。教育を受けることも含め、お金が無いと何もできない。お金がある人は外国へ移住するという考え方が根づいています。教育も然り。教養を養う教育ではなく、働くことができるための教育という印象を受けます。ヒーローはサッカー選手で、スパイクも買えなかった道端でサッカーをしている子供たちの中から、世界に通用するサッカー選手が輩出されています。サッカー選手に憧れてサッカーをするように、コタクンデも子供たちの手本となり、お金をかけなくてもカホンを叩いたり、踊ったりすることが楽しいことだと知ってもらい、夢を持って欲しいと思います。それが、アイデンティティの自覚と自信につながっていくと思います。正しい伝統文化を継承し、夢を与え、文化を通して生きる力の基礎を養って欲しいと思っています。音楽やダンスを通じて、広く深くアフロペルービアンの歴史と文化を継承していくためのこのプロジェクト、既に公立学校や教育機関よりオファーをいただいています。また、外国人の私がこの文化の持つエネルギーに生きる力をもらっているように、ペルー国内のみならず、世界にもこの文化を広く知ってもらい、伝えていきたいと思っています。

終わりに

最後になりましたが、このプロジェクトの協力者、北米の南部でアフリカンカルチャーと現代文化との融合を、時にアーティストの目で、時にプロデユーサーの目で見ている同級生、ユウコ・野上・テーラーさんに心から感謝をいたします。

ESPAÑOL

Qué es Kota-Kunde?

Kota-Kunde es un producto del inigualable maestro de la cultura afroperuana, el maestro Lalo Izquierdo y sus líderes seleccionados de la próxima generación. Creo que su trabajo es un importante proyecto de sucesión cultural para la próxima generación. Una vez me dijo: “Trabajo contigo, ya no con esa compañía. Entonces, si te has ido, no queda nadie. El maestro del alma decidió confiar mucho en mí y dijo finalmente que "este proyecto iría solo contigo". 

El proyecto que necesito revivir con su apoyo es un mini documental de tres partes, una historia sobre cultura afroperuana  y un espectáculo. La tragedia para este perfecto proyecto de nuestros sueños sucedió hace 4 años. Era demasiado tarde para cancelar una filmación que ya había sido coordinada a través de la compañía, pagada en su totalidad por mí, y que sigue siendo mi deuda privada. Fuimos estafados por el ex productora que fue procesado pero que no enfrenta a la justicia hasta el día de hoy. 

Heredar la cultura tradicional

Hoy mi proyecto me necesita en todos los sentidos. Tengo que revivir este proyecto. Desafortunadamente, en Perú casi no existe un sistema para heredar la cultura tradicional y, por lo tanto, todo está cambiando y fluyendo en la dirección comercial. Los creadores y sostenedores de la cultura afroperuana lamentan esta situación. Me preocupa mucho que esta maravillosa y verdadera tradición pueda enfrentar la extinción. Todos los miembros están muy emocionados de reiniciar. Está lleno de energía muy positiva. Lo único que necesitamos son los fondos. La música afroperuana tiene algunos ritmos típicos. El Kota-Kunde 1 del proyecto Zapateo estaba dormido en 2015 y el Kota-Kunde 2 de Festejo, planea disparar de nuevo este año. Estos son dos documentales de ritmo que necesitan financiación para alcanzar su verdadero potencial, una oportunidad que es crítica en la cúspide de este punto de inflexión histórico. Este proyecto tiene como objetivo transmitir la historia y la cultura de los afroperuanos a través de la música y la danza. Estamos seguros de que ya ha recibido ofertas para exposiciones de escuelas públicas e instituciones educativas. Los niños peruanos están divididos por una enorme brecha salarial. Los niños que juegan fútbol en la carretera a menudo no pueden pagar chimpunes, pero pueden soñar con convertirse en jugadores de fútbol de clase mundial. Al igual que un jugador de fútbol exitoso es considerado como un modelo a seguir para los niños en muchas clases socioeconómicas, Kota-Kunde también puede ser un modelo para nuestros hijos. Es divertido bailar al ritmo de Cajon sin gastar mucho dinero, dando la oportunidad de soñar y expresarse. Creo que este fundamento cultural nos lleva a reconocer y fortalecer su identidad. Queremos que todos hereden la cultura tradicional, dar sueños y cultiven los cimientos del poder de vivir. 

Perfil de productora

Nací en Tokio y afortunadamente tenía un ambiente hogareño donde siempre podía escuchar música occidental. Comencé a tocar instrumentos musicales a la edad de tres años y también me familiarice con la música pop occidental. Me enamoré de Bossa Nova, Samba, Funk, Reggae, Jazz, Blues, Salsa y todo tipo de música. Estaba particularmente fascinada por la música latina. Esto me llevó a desear una vida en América del Sur. Visité Perú por primera vez en 1999 y me fascinó la energía de la tierra y la gente. Mi casa ahora está en Perú. Aquí encontré música afroperuana y me di cuenta de que toda mi música favorita era de raíces africanas. 

En esta tierra de mis sueños, mi vida continúa de maneras inesperadas. Si bien disfruté este esfuerzo único, tuve que pasar por un divorcio en 2011. Soporté el divorcio con mis dos hijas mientras también combatía el cáncer. No hace falta decir que me costó mucho criar a dos hijas jóvenes y sobrevivir en un país extranjero. Amigos locales peruanos y amigos afroperuanos nos ayudaron a alimentarme a mí y a mi familia a través de su música peruana. Fue mi confirmación; El mundo de la música y el baile afroperuano había sido mi vida. He estado con estas personas musicales conmovedoras y he estado interactuando con ellos como verdaderos familiares.

Mi pasión

Mi pasión se extendió y en 2015, una mujer peruana presentada por un músico me ofreció un puesto como directora musical. Emocionantemente, me convertí en socia de la empresa. Yo apasionadamente, en nombre del arte y de difundir el arte peruano al mundo, comencé a producir grupos y seleccioné una fusión de música peruana tradicional y contemporánea. Sin embargo, la mujer se asoció con un famoso director de televisión francés y tomó el precioso dinero que me habían financiado muchas personas sinceras y vulnerables. Todavía no quiero rendirme. 

La próxima generación

Quiero dar a conocer esta cultura no solo en Perú, sino también en todo el mundo. Veo un gran poder en el poder y el valor de esta tradición cultural y espero que otros puedan compartir esa visión. Gracias por financiar a Kota-Kunde, y por creer en mí y en mis compañeros músicos afroperuanos y en alimentar un sueño para revivir culturas latentes pero vivas y conmovedoras para la próxima generación. 

Agradecimiento

Por último, pero no menos importante, menciono a Yuko N. Taylor, una compañero del colegio que cooperó con este proyecto que ha visto la fusión de la cultura africana y la cultura moderna en la parte sur de América del Norte a través de la vista de una artista y la vista de una productora.
story_txt: ENGLISH, 日本語, ESPAÑOLENGLISHWhat is Kota-KundeKota-Kunde is a product of the unrivaled master of the Afro-Peruvian culture, Maestro Lalo Izquierdo and his selected leaders of the next generation. I think his work is an important project of cultural succession to the next generation. He once said to me, “I work with you, not with that company anymore. So, if you are gone, no one remains.” The master of soul chose to trust me very much saying finally “this project would go only with you.”  The project I need to revive with your support is a three-part mini-documentary, a story about afro peruvian culture, and a show. Tragedy for this perfect project of our dreams happened 4 years ago.  It was too late to cancel a film shoot that was already coordinated through the company, paid in full by me, and it has remained my private debt.  We were scammed by the former producer who was prosecuted but not facing justice to this day.   All to inherit the traditional culture​Today my project needs me in every way. I have to revive this project.  Unfortunately in Peru there is almost no system for inheriting traditional culture and therefore, everything is changing and flowing in the commercial direction. The creators and sustainers of the Afro-Peruvian culture are lamenting this situation. I am very concerned that this wonderful true tradition could face extinction.  All the members are very excited to restart. It is full of very positive energy. The only thing we need is the funds. Afro-Peruvian music has some typical rhythms. The Kota-Kunde 1 of the Zapateo project was asleep in 2015 and the Kota-Kunde 2 of Festejo, plans to shoot new this year.  These are two rhythm documentaries that need funding to reach their true potential, an opportunity that is critical at the cusp of this historical turning point. This project aims to pass on the history and culture of Afro-Peruvian through music and dance. We are confident as it has already received offers for exhibitions from public schools and educational institutions. Peruvian children are divided by a huge wage gap. The children playing soccer on the roadside often cannot afford cleats, yet they can have dreams of becoming world-class soccer players.  Just like a successful soccer player is regarded as a role model for children across many socioeconomic classes, Kota-Kunde can also be a model for our children.  It is fun to dance with the rhythm of Cajon without spending a lot of money, yielding a chance to dream and express.  I think such cultural foundation leads us to both recognize and strengthen its identity. We want all to inherit the traditional culture, give dreams, and cultivate the foundation of the power to live through.Profile of producerI was born in Tokyo and had a fortunate home environment where I could always listen to Western music. I started playing musical instruments at the age of three and became familiar with Western pop music as well. I became fond of Bossa Nova, Samba, Funk, Reggae, Jazz, Blues, Salsa, and all kinds of music. I was particularly fascinated by Latin music.  This led me to desire a life in South America. I visited Peru for the first time in 1999 and was fascinated by the energy of land and people. My home is now in Peru. Here I encountered Afro-Peruvian music and realized that all of my favorite music was of African roots.In this dream land of mine my life goes on in unexpected ways.  While I enjoyed this unique endeavor, I had to go through divorce in 2011. I endured the divorce with my two daughters whilst also developing and fighting cancer. Needless to say I had a hard time raising two young daughters and surviving in a foreign land.   Local Peruvian friends and Afro-Peruvian friends helped feed energy to me and my family through their Peruvian music.  It was my confirmation; the world of Afro-Peruvian music and dance had been my life.  I have been with these soulful musical people and have been interacting with them like true families.My PassionMy passion has extended and in 2015, a Peruvian woman introduced by a musician offered me a position as a music director.   Excitingly, I became a partner of the company.  I passionately, in the name of the art and of spreading Peruvian art to the world started to produce some groups that I selected a fusion of Peruvian traditional and contemporary music. However, the woman has teamed up with a famous French television director and took the precious money which had been funded to me from many heartfelt and vulnerable people. I still do not want to give up. For next generationI want to make this culture known not only in Peru, but also across the world. I see great power in the power and value of this cultural tradition and I hope others can share in that vision.  Thank you for financing Kota-Kunde, and believing in me and my fellow Afro-Peruvian musicians and feeding a dream to revive dormant but lively soulful cultures for the  next generation.  Special Thanks to Last but not least, I give a mention of Yuko N. Taylor, a classmate who cooperated with this project who has seen the fusion of African culture and modern culture in the southern part of North America through the eyes of an artist and the eyes of a producer. 日本語コタクンデとは？文化継承・教育プロジェクト。 アフロペルービアンの歴史と伝統文化を、音楽やダンスを通して、広く深く次世代に継承していく、また世界に広めていくためのプロジェクト。コタクンデ（美しい心の意味）は、アフロペルービアン文化の世界では知らない人はいない巨匠、ラロ・イスキエルドと彼の選んだ次世代のリーダーたちのユニットです。このプロジェクトはミニドキュメンタリー、巨匠のアフロペルービアン文化の話（質問・回答形式）、ショーの３部構成です。教育機関や文化イベントに提供していきます。 アフロペルービアン音楽には、大きく分けると４つの典型的なリズムがありますが、そのうちの２つ、サパテオ（タップダンス）のコタクンデ１、フェステホのコタクンデ２、今年はまずはこの２つにフォーカスします。なぜ資金が必要かアフロペルービアンの音楽やダンスは、パーティーやイベントなどには必ず使われ、ペルー全国の人が知っています。ただそれは、商業的なものに形を変えてしまっており、本来のものとかけ離れていっています。残念ながら、ペルーには芸術的な伝統文化を継承するシステムが、ほぼ存在しません。アフロペルー文化の巨匠たちは2世の世代にあたり、すでに高齢です。このままでは、この伝統文化は正しく継承できず、絶えてしまいます。前出の２つのテーマのミニドキュメンタリー完成のための資金が必要です。お礼のアイテム（リターン）プロジェクトの目的に合わせて、みなさまに知っていただき、楽しんでいただけるあるいは学んでいただけるお礼を中心にご用意しています。特に一般の方に馴染みやすいのは、・Jarana Criolla 15$(プライベートライブビデオ)　・Video Cajon Lesson with musica 50$（カホンレクチャーを含むライブビデオ）だと思います。カホンを習得したい方には、レッスンビデオやバーチャルレッスンがあります。また、文化イベント主催者の方向けリターンもございます。すべて各々をクリックすると、日本語での詳細説明が見られます。また、BACK story:
Please make sure the English subtitles are turned on in the video above.

***CAMPAIGN UPDATES***

Every donation beyond $15,000 still makes a difference! Any funds beyond the target will still reach Al-Maa Bookstore, ensure its permanent sustainability, and will give Hamzeh greater capacity to invest in his mission of making books flow as freely as water.

1. With a few days to go in the campaign, we are almost at our goal of $15,000! THANK YOU! 

2. Atlas Obscura just published a beautiful article on Hamzeh and al-Maa. Please share widely!

3. You can now see a preview of what the calligraphy perk will look like! Click on the picture to see the video of Hussein painting it. 

Mission

Like his father, grandfather, and great-grandfather before him, Hamzeh AlMaaytah has devoted his life to books (Wiki). He named his store al-Maa, which means Water, because he believes that reading is like water for the soul.

In Jerusalem before 1948, and in Amman ever since then, this philosophy has made al-Maa into far more than a bookstore. Hamzeh welcomes all visitors with a warm heart and an open mind, inviting them to mingle underneath the book-lined walls of al-Maa. People of all religions meet there; Jordanians, expats, and refugees; and the rich, the poor, and the homeless.

Before Jordan opened its first public library, al-Maa lent books to the people of Amman. Today, Hamzeh makes sure that even the least privileged patrons can read. Anyone can borrow or exchange a book for the token sum of 1 dinar ($1.41), and there are public shelves outside the store, where passersby can take books and pay whatever they can afford.

Because of Hamzeh’s devotion to fostering peace and opening minds, he refuses to sell books that go against that mission, such as ones that incite anti-Semitism. His dedication to creating empathy between diverse groups of people is exactly why the world has never been in greater need of people like Hamzeh and communities like al-Maa.

Al-Maa is dedicated to secondhand and older books, but there is nothing old about Hamzeh’s ideas. For the last 17 years, he has been innovating ways to promote reading: from book fairs in refugee camps to traveling bookstores on donkey carts; from teaching youth the art of restoring Arabic manuscripts to holding poetry slams for the whole neighborhood. 

(Hamzeh reading under the Bedouin tent that stood outside of the store.)

This Campaign

Al-Maa suffered a serious financial setback in 2016, due to a combination of economic conditions in Jordan and a sudden illness which made Hamzeh temporarily unable to work for several months. Hamzeh, now 35, is also responsible for supporting his wife and five children. 

This Indiegogo campaign is an urgent call for help. The funds raised through this page will ensure al-Maa Bookstore's short-term financial stability. And most importantly, this campaign will empower Hamzeh to keep al-Maa open for the long-term, building on his amazing work in the community while restructuring the store as a sustainable source of income for his family. 

You can be part of saving al-Maa Bookstore. Every contribution counts, and al-Maa Bookstore will receive the funds even if the funding goal is only partially reached.

The campaign is a collaboration between the Jordanian and American friends of al-Maa Bookstore:

  • Hussein Alazaat, the Jordanian founder of the campaign and of the al-Maa branding, is a designer and contemporary calligrapher who also cofounded the philanthropic organization Wajha. Hussein believes that Hamzeh and al-Maa are the key to passing on the Arab legacy and culture to the youth of Amman. 
  • Alan Elbaum, like countless foreigners before him, found a home away from home in al-Maa Bookstore. After experiencing Hamzeh's unparalleled hospitality—cup after cup of sage tea, and conversation ranging from the Da Vinci Code to the parallels between Judaism and Islam—Alan came to love al-Maa Bookstore from the bottom of his heart, and sees Hamzeh as one of his greatest inspirations. 

How You Can Help

  1. If you have the means, please donate whatever you can afford. Claim one or more perks: from specially designed al-Maa Bookmarks, to an original poem by Hamzeh, to books about bookstores, to your name in beautiful modernized Arabic calligraphy.
  2. Whether or not you can donate, it's just as important to get the word out. If you know two or three people passionate about reading, or the Middle East, or intercultural dialogue, use the Indiegogo share tools above, or send them an email. Chances are they'd love to learn about this campaign and play a role in the incredible work Hamzeh is doing.
  3. Follow al-Maa Bookstore on social media: 
    • Facebook (@almaabookstore)
    • Twitter (@hamzeh2003)
    • Hamzeh's personal Facebook page
    • Hamzeh's Instagram (aljahith_treasury). 
  4. And finally, leave a comment on this Indiegogo page, especially if you're someone who has a personal story about Hamzeh and al-Maa Bookstore. 

Impact

At a time in history when many good people feel powerless—especially in the US and in the Middle East—this campaign is one way for you to make a concrete difference. All money raised will go toward promoting the culture of reading in the Middle East, spreading peace through books, and preserving a unique cultural inheritance for the youth of today and for future generations. 

Specifically, these are the projects you will be supporting: 

Short-term goals (within the first 6 months)

  • Renovating and expanding the store. Hamzeh needs to revitalize the storefront and renovate the interior, in addition to renewing the licensing and paying outstanding rent. He can double the area inside by expanding into the unit next door, which will make the space suitable for bigger gatherings and cultural events. The place also needs plaster and paint on the walls, a bathroom, and new shelves. Hamzeh plans to make the shelves movable so he can display books outside, move the shelves whenever he hosts an event in the store, and easily take the books on the road for his book fairs. 

(Illustration for the exterior shelves by Jonah Coe-Scharff.)

  • Establishing a literary and cultural salon. For decades, al-Maa Bookstore has been a place of gathering for all lovers of books—rich and poor, foreign and local. Once the store has received its much-needed renovations, Hamzeh will be able to resume hosting evenings of discussion, literature, and music. The bookstore will once again be a sanctuary of peace and mingling of cultures on the busy, loud streets of downtown Amman.  
  • Books in the community. Al-Maa Bookstore can create jobs and bring books to the wider community at the same time. Hamzeh plans to hire low-income residents of Amman who are having trouble seeking jobs to bring books across the city by bicycle or donkey, with a particular emphasis on children's books. 

Medium-term goals (within the first 12 months)

  • Book fairs in schools. In recent years, Al-Maa Bookstore has already run seven successful book fairs in different cities and universities across Jordan, including in the local schools for boys and girls run by UNRWA (the agency for Palestinian refugees in Jordan). Hamzeh intends to expand this program to bring the book fair to many more primary and secondary schools in underprivileged areas, with an emphasis on education for girls.

(Hamzeh's book fair at the German Jordanian University in May 2016.)

  • Book fairs in prisons. Hamzeh also intends to launch book fairs in prisons, believing that inmates should have the right to borrow and exchange books like anybody else. Through this program, Hamzeh will also invite and teach inmates to write about their experiences, and he plans to publish an anthology of their original work. 
  • Book fairs in refugee camps. Hamzeh has a deep concern for the welfare of the refugees who have flowed into Jordan—whether Palestinian, Iraqi, or Syrian—and has employed them in al-Maa Bookstore when business is good. He plans to work with organizations supporting refugees, in order to transfer his book fair model to refugee camps. 

Long-term Goals

  • Radio show. Hamzeh's idea is to interview both readers and writers, anybody with a gift for poetry, and especially elders from different tribes and rural areas. He sees recording and broadcasting these interviews as a powerful way to preserve folk traditions and dialects of Jordan—and also to make the culture of reading accessible to people who are blind through audio recordings. 
  • A museum for rare Arabic books. Hamzeh, together with his brothers, is the custodian of al-Jahith's Treasury, an archive that was founded by his father Mamduh, and rapidly became one of the great private collections of rare books and manuscripts in the region. The treasures of the collection are not for sale, but Hamzeh wants to make them accessible to the public by transforming the inside of the bookstore into a museum for rare Arabic books. It will also be a laboratory where he can teach young people the art of restoring and digitizing old books.

(Hamzeh holding up one of the rare Arabic manuscripts owned by the family.)

Other Ways to Help

If you have any other ideas for how to help Hamzeh's campaign, please send us an email at mahall.almaa@gmail.com, and cc: Hussein <me@alazaat.com> and Alan <alanelbaum@gmail.com>. 

Possibilities include:

  • Matching donations up to a certain value;
  • Donating a perk;
  • Connecting us to an NGO;
  • Connecting us to a foundation, or recommending a grant to apply for;
  • Design work for the campaign and for al-Maa in general;
  • Pro bono business consulting for al-Maa to rework its business plan;
  • Writing a press release, or advertising this campaign any other way;
  • The ways to help are limitless! All suggestions are welcome. 

Reliability

Alongside Hamzeh's passion and vision, he brings 17 years of experience in the book trade. He has been running al-Maa Bookstore in its current location since 2000.

Hamzeh already laid the groundwork for most of these projects prior to his major health and economic setback last summer. He has conducted 7 book fairs and workshops in recent years, both in Amman and in the surrounding towns. Through these initiatives he closely cooperated with the local municipalities and ministries, whose support and funding will make these programs sustainable going forward.

Although the economic climate in Jordan remains challenging, Hamzeh's health has improved, and with your support he will be able to build on these initiatives and guarantee that al-Maa's legacy will continue for future generations. 

Hussein Alazaat, a native of Jordan and a graduate of the London Art College, brings nearly a decade of experience in the field of design in Amman. Most significantly, he cofounded the Wajha Project in 2012, a charitable social initiative which helps small business owners revitalize their branding. With Hussein's years of experience working with traditional shop owners such as Hamzeh, he is contributing the practical skills to help Hamzeh turn his vision into a reality. 

Links

Wikipedia on al-Jahith's Treasury

Hussein Alazaat on what Hamzeh's bookstore means to him

A Jordan Bookseller’s 24-Hour ‘Emergency Room for the Mind’

Please make sure the English subtitles are turned on in the video above.***CAMPAIGN UPDATES***Every donation beyond $15,000 still makes a difference! Any funds beyond the target will still reach Al-Maa Bookstore, ensure its permanent sustainability, and will give Hamzeh greater capacity to invest in his mission of making books flow as freely as water.1. With a few days to go in the campaign, we are almost at our goal of $15,000! THANK YOU! 2. Atlas Obscura just published a beautiful article on Hamzeh and al-Maa. Please share widely!3. You can now see a preview of what the calligraphy perk will look like! Click on the picture to see the video of Hussein painting it. MissionLike his father, grandfather, and great-grandfather before him, Hamzeh AlMaaytah has devoted his life to books (Wiki). He named his store al-Maa, which means Water, because he believes that reading is like water for the soul.In Jerusalem before 1948, and in Amman ever since then, this philosophy has made al-Maa into far more than a bookstore. Hamzeh welcomes all visitors with a warm heart and an open mind, inviting them to mingle underneath the book-lined walls of al-Maa. People of all religions meet there; Jordanians, expats, and refugees; and the rich, the poor, and the homeless.Before Jordan opened its first public library, al-Maa lent books to the people of Amman. Today, Hamzeh makes sure that even the least privileged patrons can read. Anyone can borrow or exchange a book for the token sum of 1 dinar ($1.41), and there are public shelves outside the store, where passersby can take books and pay whatever they can afford.Because of Hamzeh’s devotion to fostering peace and opening minds, he refuses to sell books that go against that mission, such as ones that incite anti-Semitism. His dedication to creating empathy between diverse groups of people is exactly why the world has never been in greater need of people like Hamzeh and communities like al-Maa.Al-Maa is dedicated to secondhand and older books, but there is nothing old about Hamzeh’s ideas. For the last 17 years, he has been innovating ways to promote reading: from book fairs in refugee camps to traveling bookstores on donkey carts; from teaching youth the art of restoring Arabic manuscripts to holding poetry slams for the whole neighborhood. (Hamzeh reading under the Bedouin tent that stood outside of the store.)This CampaignAl-Maa suffered a serious financial setback in 2016, due to a combination of economic conditions in Jordan and a sudden illness which made Hamzeh temporarily unable to work for several months. story:
Inspire communication-human connection-imagination 

In our project there are more than 50 people rehearsing and finally on stage (many of them for the first time!) singing, dancing, balancing and interacting with the audience. Giant puppets, stiltwalking heroes, trapeeze, silks and monocycles.  Performers range from 4-60 years of age and come from many different countries-cultures. Everyone has their own story and we will sing together the oldest written story on earth, about Gilgamesh and how he uses his great power to conquer nature and chase immortality through material wealth. We end by showing that the same story has been playing for at least 5000 years and that we need to stop giving our lives to build towers for the rich and powerful. Opera Babel, our group of players speak many different languages, but the theme of the show is to understand each other and create a world based on balance and harmony.

"Once upon a time
Maybe yours
Maybe mine
Friends of friends
and Fred's friends met..
Dancers, musicians and creators, of many arts and fields and
sectors...
Travellers, fathers and daughters,
Searchers, researchers and
farmers,
Started narrating their own way
An ancient story of huge fame..

Between two Rivers
We'll meet Gilgamesh
And
revive the Babel's mess ..
With a
puppet, a magic carpet, flutes, and strings and aerial
swings...
We will sing with voices made of challenge choices...
Gods and Kings,
Decisions and missions..
Tales
of friendship, love and faith
Ventures,
adventures through war and fame..
Come to see if you wonder why
would someone try
to reach myth,
his dream, or even sky."

story:
My name is Ben Berman, the US-based fundraising coordinator for Steve's project! For many  years now Steve Appiah has been spreading the gift of kente weaving from his native Ghana in the community of Johannesburg, South Africa. He has taught unemployed adults and at-risk youth to realize their creative potentials and support themselves. Now, Steve is trying to expand his reach--he is starting an ambitious revamping of the building where his studio is. He envisions the building to become a center where he and other local artists can teach and sell their crafts to others in the community. He is already doing renovations himself, but he needs enough funds for more tools and supplies, as well as for permits and a license to operate some of the rooms as a new guesthouse.

How did a random American end up raising money for a Ghanaian weaver? I was blessed to first meet Steve in a time of need when I first traveled to South Africa. I was mugged on my second day in Joburg, my wallet and phone stolen--unfortunately a not uncommon experience for first-time visitors to some South African cities, with the country's stark inequality and crime. Thankfully I was unharmed, and a few locals helped me safely get around to buy a new phone and contact the hostel I was staying at. Steve happened to be at the phone store and overheard me telling someone what had happened, and he introduced himself, showing me his business card.

For the next couple days Steve took me around the city, introducing me to his family and friends, and showing me some of the city's diverse, resilient communities. I was completely safe with him being a local. He took time out of his busy life--working his weaving, repairing shoes, and helping his kids on their homework--to be a private guide for me, a stranger. Steve helped me find a bus to my next destination, and continued to check in with me over the next two months as I went around the country. When I came back to Joburg before flying home, he insisted on hosting me in his weaving studio for a few days.

So to give back to how Steve and other people around Joburg welcomed me, I'm now trying to get support for Steve to take his art and teaching work with the community to another level. Now that South Africa has moved out of its months-long period of COVID lockdowns, people are out and about again. Steve is currently doing a lot of painting, wire and pipe repair, landscaping, and other cleaning himself day in an day out, but he needs money for more supplies and early rent as he prepares, in this crucial stage, to open his center in January. Even small contributions are extremely helpful, as 1 US dollar converts to 17 South African rands and can go far when added up. This is not just another corporate charity fund of throwing money at African governments to save statistics from famine and disease; this is a way to contribute meaningfully to a project run by locals to empower other locals, something that will make a long-term impact in people's lives.

Here is an article about Steve's work from a few years ago:

https://northcliffmelvilletimes.co.za/244528/me...
