story:
Srcoll down for English

42 años de cine

La Cinemateca del Museo La Tertulia se inauguró el 6 de marzo de 1975 convirtiéndose pronto en uno de los espacios emblemáticos de la cultura en el país y uno de los lugares más queridos por los caleños. La ciudad, durante los años 70 y 80, lideró a nivel nacional el movimiento cinéfilo y cinematográfico, y la Cinemateca fue el lugar de encuentro, reflexión y discusión tanto de realizadores como de espectadores que se formaron en esta sala de cortinas rojas ante el encanto de las proyecciones en 35 mm. Quedan grabadas en la memoria las largas filas para las películas de la nueva ola, el nuevo cine latinoamericano, el cine político europeo.

En el nuevo milenio, las transformaciones de la industria y las estrategias de distribución, así como las crisis económicas, debilitaron su presencia en el panorama de la cultura nacional.

A pesar de las dificultades, durante los últimos años La Tertulia ha logrado generar nuevamente interés por la Cinemateca y reavivar su presencia en la agenda cultural de la ciudad. Se han realizado transformaciones en su infraestructura gracias al apoyo del Ministerio de Cultura. En 2016 se adquirió un proyector digital DCP, con sonido Dolby 5.1. La Cinemateca se reincorporó al circuito de exhibición y la programación ha elevado su nivel con estrenos, directores invitados, muestras y festivales internacionales.

Sin embargo, aún nos queda mucho por mejorar.

La Nueva Cinemateca

Nos estamos reinventando, convertiremos a la Cinemateca La Tertulia en una plataforma vital de exhibición y experimentación audiovisual, en un espacio de encuentro para la ciudad  y una ventana a la cinematografía internacional más relevante. 

Tras adecuaciones técnicas, hoy nos preparamos para reformas físicas que cambiarán por siempre el rostro de nuestra Sala; cambiaremos nuestros pisos, silletería e iluminación gracias al apoyo del Ministerio de Cultura, pero aún quedan  aspectos por mejorar para convertirnos en la Cinemateca que soñamos.

Lanzamos este Crowdfunding para invitar a nuestro público a hacer parte de nuestra transformación.

Con tu apoyo lograremos

  • Terminar el proceso de renovación del espacio (una nueva cartelera, ingreso a la sala y taquilla).
  • Reforzar la programación con líneas que incorporen, además de los géneros clásicos, los nuevos modos de experimentación y los cruces contemporáneos con otros formatos y disciplinas.
  • Invitar a más directores, editores, actores, músicos, programadores, artistas y otros colegas a que expandan nuestros conocimientos sobre el cine y las artes cinemáticas.
  • Editar una serie de publicaciones que nos permitan ir más allá de las proyecciones
    e incentivar la crítica cinematográfica y la investigación.
  • Iniciar el proceso de conservación de nuestro archivo de afiches que cuenta con casi 3.000 ejemplares.

Al Sumarte a #LaNuevaCinemateca

La Tertulia tendrá de nuevo una sala de proyección de primer nivel, con una oferta cinematográfica alternativa y una agenda de eventos e invitados que fomentará la formación de públicos. Volveremos a ser un escenario vital del cine regional y nacional, y una ventana para las obras más interesantes de la cinematografía mundial. 

#LaNuevaCinemateca se convertirá en un referente de las artes y la creación audiovisual.

Apóyanos con tu donación y llévate una valiosa parte de la historia de este emblemático recinto a tu casa: un preciado juego de las  sillas clásicas de la Cinemateca!!!

Revisa las condiciones de nuestra campaña y haz parte del nacimiento de #LaNuevacinemateca !!  

 

Una vez te hayas sumado

Al finalizar los 40 días de nuestra campaña nos pondremos en contacto con nuestros donantes para realizar la gestión de entrega y envío de los beneficios adquiridos.

Los gastos de envío deben ser asumidos por el comprador. El Museo no se hace cargo de los trámites ni costos para envíos al exterior

 

¡Qué todos sepan!

Ayúdanos a divulgar nuestro proyecto, habla de #LaNuevaCinemateca como un espacio de los caleños, como un emblema de nuestra ciudad. 

Comparte nuestra iniciativa en tus redes, invita a tus amigos, vecinos y familia. ¡Queremos sumar voces! ¡Que todo Cali sepa que la Cinemateca de La Tertulia es su sala de cine!

Si quieres saber más

En el sitio web del Museo www.museolatertulia.com encuentras las respuestas a las preguntas frecuentes en relación a la campaña.

Si tienes alguna inquietud puntual no resuelta en nuestras FAQ escríbenos al correo amigos@museolatertulia.com y resolveremos tus dudas 

 

 

42 years of Cinema

The Cinemateca of  La Tertulia Museum was inaugurated on March 6, 1975 and quickly became one of the most emblematic spaces of culture in the country as well as one of the most cherished places for Caleños. During the 70s and 80s, the cinephile was born and the cinematographic movement expanded nationally. The Cinemateca became a place to meet, reflect, and discuss for both filmmakers and film-goers alike; who gathered in this red curtain room to experience the enchantment of the 35 mm projector. The long line-ups for new wave films, new Latin American cinema, European political cinema, will long be remembered.

At the start of the new millennium the  the film industry changed as a result of   distribution strategies and the economic crisis, weakening it's presence in the landscape of national culture.

In spite of these difficulties, during recent years, La Tertulia has managed to generate interest for the Cinemateca reviving it's presence in the city's cultural scene. Infrastucture changes have been made possible, thanks to the support of the Ministry of Culture. In 2016, a digital projector DCP with Dolby 5.1 sound, was purchased. The Cinemateca rejoined the exhibition circuit and its programs expanded, to include premieres, guest directors, shows and international festivals.

However, we still have much to improve.

The New Cinemateca

We are reinventing ourselves. La Tertulia Cinemateca will transformed into a  vital platform for exhibition and audiovisual experimentation, as well as, a meeting space for the city and a venue for the most relevant 

international cinematography. After technical adjustments, today we are preparing for renovations that will forever change the face of our theater. The floors, chairs and lighting will be changed, thanks to the support of the Ministry of Culture, but there are still improvements to be made in order to become the Cinemateca we envision.

We are launching Crowdfunding with an invitation to our loyal patrons to be part of our transformation. With your support we will achieve

  • Complete renovations of the space (a new billboard, hall entrance and box office)
  • Invite more directors, editors, actors, musicians, programmers, artists and other colleagues to expand our knowledge of cinema and the cinematic arts.
  • Publish a series of publications that will allow us to go beyond film projection, to the exploration of film criticism and research.
  • Start the process of conservation of our poster archive which includes almost 3,000 documents.

To be part of the #LaNuevaCineteca

La Tertulia will once again have a first-class projection room, with an alternative cinematographic program and a schedule of events and guests that will promote education in cinetographic arts. We will once again become a vital venue for regional and national cinema, events and a host of the most interesting works of art in world cinematography. #LaNuevaCinematica will become a reference for the arts and audiovisuals.

Show your support through your donation and share in La Tertulia's history by taking home a precious set of the Cinemateca theater chairs!!!

Review the conditions of our new campaign and part of La Tertulia's rebirth.

Once you have joined our campaing

At the end of our 40 day campaign, we will be contacting our donors in order to deliver or ship your purchase.

The shipments fee for purchases  has to be covered by the donor.  The Museum is not responsible for the  procedure for international shipments.  

Spread the word!

Help us share this project, so that #LaNuevaCinemateca may known as a renewed iconic space for Calenos in our city.

Share our initiative online, invite your friends, neighbors and families so that our voices may be strong and everyone in Cali recognizes La Cinematica La Tertulia is the place to see a movie.

If you want to know more, go to Museum website www.museolatertulia.com and find the answers and frequently asked questions of the campaign.

If you have concerns that are not addressed in our FAQs section, please write to us at amigos@museolatertulia.com and we will respond as soon as possible.

story:
(per leggere il testo in italiano cliccare qui)

 

Imagine..

«Imagine a society in which the cycles of life are revered and respected as quiet orchestrators of our lives - instilling a deep reverence for the planet and everything on it.  

Imagine that the menstrual cycle is understood as the heartbeat of that great orchestration and most crucially, honoured as the sacred source of life for us humans.  (…)

Imagine girls growing up in this menstrual affirming world. When a girl arrives at menarche she feels a real dignity and a strong yes to her being. (…)

Imagine a world where menopause is recognised as a healthy organic step in a woman’s evolutionary journey.»

[Alexandra Pope e Sjanie Hugo Wurlitzer]

 

I have a vision…

I have a vision, and I know it's a vision shared by many.

To manifest this vision, I need your help.

 

On January 15-20, 2019 I will participate, for the second time, at #LSUC2019, the "Learning Societies UnConference 2019", in India,  to invite a process of constructive reflection and meaningful dialogue on the topic of the female cycle, to explore and engage on a debate that NEEDS to become PUBLIC.

Among my goals, in addition to recovering a positive vision of the menstrual cycle as a powerful tool for empowerment for women of all ages, the need and urgency to involve the media in the debate.

 

Why do I want to participate in the #LSUC2019?

Since 2012 I have been working on embodied leadership for women, through the international project #REDvolutionary Weaving.. At LSUC2019 I would like to continue the constructive reflection that I have already started here, in 2016, to explore and stimulate a debate on unlearning preconceptions about the perception of women's bodies and women's cycles.

A meaningful dialogue on a theme that concerns more than half of the world's population and, yet, is still a taboo, surrounded by a halo of shame, not only in developing countries, but all over the world, including  my country, Italy.

 

 

What is the Learning Societies UnConference 2019 (LSUC2019)?

A «non» conference on the pedagogy of un_learning. This year's edition will take place in the Orissa region, in Eastern India, at Centurion University in Parlakhemundi, a few hours from Bhubaneswar.

 

    What is the goal of the Learning Societies Unconference?

    To bring together people from all over the world, innovators, ecologists, social entrepreneurs, individuals engaged in alternative and sustainable learning processes, through "unlearning", to explore new pedagogical models of happiness and well-being.

     

       

      Why #REDvolutionaryWeaving?

      Since 2012 I have been working on embodied leadership for women through the #REDvolutionary Weaving project,  a pedagogical method based on listening to the body's intelligence, using the archetype of weaving with the red thread. This is connected with the ability of women to create networks, at all levels. It  intertwine, metaphorically and literally, the stories and roots, dreams and talents of women of all ages, coming from from different countries.

       

       

      Who has participated in this project so far?

      This project started in Italy and brought me to  Lithuania, France, Belarus, Hungary, Switzerland, Turkey, India, Greece, England. In each stage I collected red thread, to be brought to the next country, as a talking bridge between the communities. I facilitated groups with women from the most varied backgrounds: from female students to entrepreneurs, with ages ranging from 13 to 103 years ..

      (in the photo below, a workshop in Lithuania)

       

      What can be my contribution to the LSUC 2019?

      I would like to offer sessions on this subject open to women and men, to broaden the perspective in an eco-systemic way.. My goal is to recover a positive vision of the women's cycle as a powerful tool for empowerment for women of all ages.

       

      Why do I want to return to this event in India?

      The pedagogy of unlearning and sustainability, in India, has solid and deep roots.
      Gandhi's  motto, "Be the change you want to see in the world", has inspired the changemakers of the world for generations. India is an exporter of best practices on the culture of change. And these best practices have inspired my work in recent years. My participation in LSUC in 2016 allowed me to meet professionals who have planted seeds for a profound transformation in my professional and personal life.

      In the picture below, from the left: Gloria Germani, a changemaker from Italy, my country;  Claude Alvares, a Wise Elder, environmentalist and a pillar in the field of sustainability in India, myself and Manish Jain, the visionary heart_mind behind the Learning Societies UnConference.

       

      Success stories and my contribution in the last edition

      The feedback I received from the sessions offered during the  LSUC 2016  was really positive. After the session, some of the participants (including men) have created spaces for reflection in their communities, to continue the conversation with other people. One of them is Suyash Saboo (left in the picture below), a facilitator who has organized a few meetings for women and men on this topic, in his city, Indore, in central India.  We have met a few times on skype, since our meeting at LSUC, to exchange notes on this theme.

       

      More on my relationship to India

      In India I had other significant experiences, always connected to the pedagogy of unlearning and  the awareness of the body. In November 2015 I was invited as an artist in residence for a month at the Srishti Institute of Art, Design and Technology, in Bangalore, to work with a group of 16 female students and an Industrial Design teacher, Tulip Sinha Neel, to develop a creative project on this topic.

       

      This is the agenda of my sessions at LSUC 2019

      • reclaiming a positive vision of the menstrual cycle as a powerful tool of empowerment for women of all ages (with presentation of the international project #REDvolutionaryWeaving, on emodied female leadership)
      • the need to de-stigmatize words like “menstrual” and “menopause”
      • the right to menstruate and to have access to menstrual hygiene for women all over the world
      • the need to bring together activists, practitioners, funders, and academics to discuss about it
      • the need to inform men as well. And to involve them in the conversation (menstruation is NOT a “woman” but a “human” issue)
      • the need to involve mainstream media in this conversation

       

       

      Why contribute to my fundraising campaign?
      Your contribution can make the difference!

      I decided to create this fundraiser to raise  awareness on this topic and involve, both women and men. I ask for your support to promote a pedagogy in favor of the dignity of women's bodies, and to cultivate a new way of relating to one's body, both for adolescents and for women of all ages.
      I would  like to be supported also by  fathers and teachers of teenage girls.

       

      How can you support me?

      Any form of generosity you wish to offer is welcome:

      -  You can help me sharing this campaign with your friends and contacts and spreading the word.

      -  with financial support to cover costs 

      • travel (visa, international flight from Italy to India and domestic flights)
      • accommodation
      •  initial investment in communication, to make this project take off. I calculated a cost of  3,000€ for the first phase, which covers the period from December to April 2019.

       

      Every donation, no matter how small or big,  will be greatly valued and will make a difference. Each person that supports this initiative will be updated at least once when I am in India and upon my return.

       

      The outputs of the first phase of the project

      December 2018 - April 2019: 
      - a video that tells the experience of LSUC,
      - a short informative e-book for men (thought especially for fathers of teenage girls)

       

      MY GIFTS TO THANK YOU

      I am also willing to give something in return (see Perks on the right side of page): I created some packages for individuals.

      I can also offer

      - group facilitation
      - collaborations with companies, schools, associations.  Please contact me privately to discuss tailor made sessions that would include training on the theme of 'embodied leadership, harvesting of the experience in India, individual coaching for HR professionals.

       

      Time frame

      The conference starts on January  15th and ends on the 20th. 
      I will travel to India on January 6th.

       

      Something about me:

      My name is Silvana Rigobon. I am a dreamweaver. I am Italian and a citizen of the world, nomad at heart. I am a facilitator and coach on diversity and inclusion  through movement and body awareness.  I trained in England with Ya'Acov and Susannah Darling Khan as a teacher of Movement Medicine. I also trained with Alexandra Pope and Sjanie Hugo Wurlitzer (co-founders of the Red School) . My background is in communication and I have collaborated with international institutions in the field of global health for several years.

       

      Useful links

      Learning Societies UnConference 2019
      http://www.shikshantar.org/lsuc
       
      Movement Medicine
      www.schoolofmovementmedicine.com
      FB: Movement Medicine
       
      Red School e tema della mestrualità
      www.redschoolonline.net
      FB:  Red School

       

      To contact me

      silvana.rigobon@gmail.com
      FB: Movement Medicine Silvana
      Twitter: @silvanaRigobon
      http://movementmedicineassociation.org/silvana-...

       

      GRAZIE! THANK YOU! #21gratitudes

Why do I want to return to this event in India?
The pedagogy of unlearning and sustainability, in India, has solid and deep roots.Gandhi's  motto, "Be the change you want to see in the world", has inspired the changemakers of the world for generations. India is an exporter of best practices on the culture of change. And these best practices have inspired my work in recent years. My participation in LSUC in 2016 allowed me to meet professionals who have planted seeds for a profound transformation in my professional and personal life.
In the picture below, from the left: Gloria Germani, a changemaker from Italy, my country;  Claude Alvares, a Wise Elder, environmentalist and a pillar in the field of sustainability in India, myself and Manish Jain, the visionary heart_mind behind the Learning Societies UnConference.

 
Success stories and my contribution in the last edition
The feedback I received from the sessions offered during the  LSUC 2016  was really positive. After the session, some of the participants (including men) have created spaces for reflection in their communities, to continue the conversation with other people. One of them is Suyash Saboo (left in the picture below), a facilitator who has organized a few meetings for women and men on this topic, in his city, Indore, in central India.  We have met a few times on skype, since our meeting at LSUC, to exchange notes on this theme.

 
More on my relationship to India
In India I had other significant experiences, always connected to the pedagogy of unlearning and  the awareness of the body. In November 2015 I was invited as an artist in residence for a month at the Srishti Institute of Art, Design and Technology, in Bangalore, to work with a group of 16 female students and an Industrial Design teacher, Tulip Sinha Neel, to develop a creative project on this topic.

 
This is the agenda of my sessions at LSUC 2019

reclaiming a positive vision of the menstrual cycle as a powerful tool of empowerment for women of all ages (with presentation of the international project #REDvolutionaryWeaving, on emodied female leadership)
the need to de-stigmatize words like “menstrual” and “menopause”
the right to menstruate and to have access to menstrual hygiene for women all over the world
the need to bring together activists, practitioners, funders, and academics to discuss about it
the need to inform men as well. And to involve them in the conversation (menstruation is NOT a “woman” but a “human” issue)
the need to involve mainstream media in this conversation

 
 
Why contribute to my fundraising campaign?Your contribution can make the difference!
I decided to create this fundraiser to raise  awareness on this topic and involve, both women and men. I ask for your support to promote a pedagogy in favor of the dignity of women's bodies, and to cultivate a new way of relating to one's body, both for adolescents and for women of all ages.I would  like to be supported also by  fathers and teachers of teenage girls.
 
How can you support me?
Any form of generosity you wish to offer is welcome:
-  You can help me sharing this campaign with your friends and contacts and spreading the word.
-  with financial support to cover costs 

travel (visa, international flight from Italy to India and domestic flights)
accommodation
 initial investment in communication, to make this project take off. I calculated a cost of  3,000€ for the first phase, which covers the period from December to April 2019.

 
Every donation, no matter how small or big,  will be greatly valued and will make a difference. Each person that supports this initiative will be updated at least once when I am in India and upon my return.
 
The outputs of the first phase of the project
December 2018 - April 2019:  - a video that tells the experience of LSUC,- a short informative e-book for men (thought especially for fathers of teenage girls)
 
MY GIFTS TO THANK YOU
I am also willing to give something in return (see Perks on the right side of page): I created some packages for individuals. 
I can also offer
- group facilitation - collaborations with companies, schools, associations.  Please contact me privately to discuss tailor made sessions that would include training on the theme of 'embodied leadership, harvesting of the experience in India, individual coaching for HR professionals.
 
Time frame
The conference starts on January  15th and ends on the 20th. I will travel to India on January 6th.
 
Something about me:
My name is Silvana Rigobon. I am a dreamweaver. I am Italian and a citizen of the world, nomad at heart. I am a facilitator and coach on diversity and inclusion  through movement and body awareness.  I trained in England with Ya'Acov and Susannah Darling Khan as a teacher of Movement Medicine. I also trained with Alexandra Pope and Sjanie Hugo Wurlitzer (co-founders of the Red School) . My background is in communication and I have collaborated with international institutions in the field of global health for several years.
 
Useful links
Learning Societies UnConference 2019http://www.shikshantar.org/lsuc Movement Medicinewww.schoolofmovementmedicine.comFB: Movement Medicine Red School e tema della mestrualitàwww.redschoolonline.netFB:  Red School
 
To contact me
silvana.rigobon@gmail.comFB: Movement Medicine SilvanaTwitter: @silvanaRigobonhttp://movementmedicineassociation.org/silvana-...
 
GRAZIE! THANK YOU! #21gratitudes

story:
Sudbury, Ontario is a booming film production centre and needs a community partner to ensure locally-produced films and world-class indie gems have a big screen they can count on year-round.
 
Sudbury Indie Cinema  is a not-for-profit co-operative based in Northern Ontario, Canada. We currently host screenings "pop -up" style from a variety of venues in downtown Sudbury, hosting festivals and film series. Our dream from day 1 has been to move into our own downtown location to be open year-round to the public. We are very close...!

Finally, after 5 long years of grant writing and living from project to project, the key government partners have 'greenlit' our organization to move forward to create the only not-for-profit independent movie house in Northern Ontario dedicated year-round to bring the best in world cinema. Over 70% of the monies required are already in place.

We currently have 540 co-op members and dozens of community partners. Together, we are working hard to raise our contribution towards the renovation and equipment costs to open this coming fall at 162 Mackenzie St, Sudbury. Opening on Mackenzie St. involves re-purposing a former school gymnasium to become a state-of-the-art single screen, 180 seat, fully digital movie theatre. This could pave the way for more arts organizations to move into the school to create an arts and culture cluster in a beautiful, historic building that has laid empty for over ten years.   
The support and goodwill of many, to get to this point, has been key. Your support now is extremely important to help us pay our portion of cinema seating, a digital projector and screen, sound equipment, the box office amenities, everything related to our concessions stand, as well as renovations. 

There are so many who benefit from our project going ahead. Here's a few:
1. Local & Visiting Film-Lovers: having access to the best films being made in Canada and around the world today on the big screen, everyday- year round. Not just on special occasions.
2. Independent Film-Makers, especially Canadian: our Canadian filmmakers need industry partners in order to reach audiences. When high caliber films premiere at Sundance, Cannes, TIFF or Cinefest that shouldn't be the end of the film's story on the big screen. We will pick up where festivals leave off, giving laudable films a proper theatrical run. 
3. Local Filmmakers- emerging to established. Sudbury Indie Cinema goes out of its way to give those interested in film and already making films a venue they can count on. Whether that's us running professional development opportunities, mentorship programmes, being a test screening location or selecting local films for screening- we are genuinely committed to Northerners being in the driver's seat, telling our stories. 
4. Marginalized Groups, Lesser-Heard Voices: At the core of our mission is our commitment to bringing lesser heard voices to the big screen. That means that we intentionally work against the biases in the film industry itself to ensure that the film subjects and makers reflect a diversity of voices. 
5.  Other Community Causes & Arts Groups: Sudbury Indie Cinema is proactive in selecting film programming which can serve as a springboard for social causes, public awareness, fundraising,  and community-building led by others. We work cooperatively with a variety of community partners every year to help them get their message out and expand their reach. When you help us, you help another 20 organizations have a platform through our co-productions and associations.

story:
ZORA'S HOUSE IS A PLACE WHERE WOMEN OF COLOR COME TO WORK, PLAY, AND SOCIALIZE.

Something magical happens when dope women gather in spaces created specifically with them in mind. Friendships are formed. Business ideas are hatched. Careers are elevated. Wine is consumed!

Zora’s House is just such a space!

Part social club, part coworking studio, part workshop and event space, at Zora’s House you can curl up with a new Toni Morrison book one day, attend a workshop on self-love or marketing a passion based business the next, and wrap up the week with a yoga class infused with jazz music and spoken word poetry.

614 TAKEOVER.

When I first moved to Columbus in the summer of 2015, I was immediately homesick for the life that I had left behind.

I started looking for places that would allow me to meet like-minded women of color friends and events that spoke to my interests, but was frustrated to find that many events were either "social" or "professional," and none of the programming or places I came across were really dedicated to helping me cultivate meaningful relationships or build my long-term local support system.

I finally realized that what I was looking for didn't exist. And from there, the idea for Zora's House was born.

Zora's House is founded on the belief that women of color in Columbus deserve a beautiful place to work, teach, learn, and meet others, and that’s exactly what we’re creating.

COMMUNITY + OPPORTUNITY.

The coworking space is the easiest thing to point to, but Zora’s House is more than a workplace. We also offer classes, skills training, a library full of books by women of color authors, meeting space, a residency program, and evening events. The heart of Zora’s House is our community of like-minded women who support, collaborate with, and learn from one another.

PROVEN MODEL. EXPANDED REACH.

In February of 2016, we started a Meetup group called Zora’s Daughters to test the market desire for a space like Zora’s House. In the months since, our group has grown to over nine hundred members and we have hosted fourteen events (including book club meetings, pop up coworking sessions, leadership workshops, and more) reaching over three hundred women in our target community.

In other words, the transformative power of community and empowerment that Zora’s House is founded on has already begun to transform the lives of women of color in Columbus. Now with the opening of Zora’s House, we are looking to expand our community, our programming, and our impact!

JOIN OUR TRIBE.

Zora's House membership is ideal for any woman interested in joining (or supporting) a community of kick ass women of color.

WHERE THE MONEY WILL GO.

The Zora’s House train has left the station! Our space is built and the team is coming together! We've created this crowdfunding campaign to engage our future community members early on, in hopes that you will help us make Zora’s House even better.

The more money raised now, the better able we are to create a space that’s not just functional and beautiful, but one that is a vibrant center  of community and opportunity for women of color in Columbus.

The funds raised in this campaign will help us complete our lending and reference library featuring women of color authors and help furnish our coworking, conference room, and small event space. Ultimately, your support will help outfit Zora’s House with shared, creative resources for women of color in the process of creating purpose driven lives and careers.

THE REWARDS.

Supporting Zora's House is a win/win. Here's how we support you when you support us!

NOT A WOMAN OF COLOR? NOT LOCAL?

At Zora's House, we believe that women and girls of color have the power to change the world. We're looking to partner with individuals and organizations that feel similarly.

Not a woman of color? Not local to Columbus, OH? Any money you contribute can be earmarked for the Zora's House scholarship fund, which will support dope and deserving women who might not otherwise be able to afford a Zora's House membership.

CAN'T AFFORD TO SUPPORT FINANCIALLY?

If you can imagine what it takes for a twenty-something year old black girl to vision, build, and operate her own space dedicated to women of color and their joy, success, and magic - then it shouldn't surprise you when I say that in a world constantly telling me to dream smaller, I am humbled by each and every person who supports this campaign - financially or otherwise.

If you're not in a place to support financially, no worries! Here are some other ways to support:

  1. Use the share buttons at the top of this page and share this project with friends who would appreciate it! We're trying to get the word out about Zora's House so please feel free to share this campaign far and wide!
  2. If you're a member of the media or know someone who is, get in touch!
  3. Send along some prayers and words of encouragement. Though we've come a long way, we've still got a ways to go and we'll take any emotional support you have to offer as we push this thing over the finish line.

Thanks in advance for your support and I look forward to seeing you one day at Zora's House!

story:
Why should you care about Yongsan Legacy project?

By the end of 2017, USFK has announced that the command units and most personnel who serve and live on Yongsan Garrison will be relocated to Camp Humphreys in Pyungtaek. In order to make room for one of the largest urban parks in the world, the current master plan for Yongsan National Urban Park plans to demolish more than 90% of approximately 1,000 existing buildings inside the base. Once the buildings and places are removed, stories and memories of the place will also vanish into the past.

Because it was an active military base, everything had to be kept secret. But after almost 70 years of Seoul’s rapid growth completely encapsulated the garrison making it an “urban archaeological site.” To many Seoulites, Yongsan Garrison is a “black hole” sitting in the middle of a megapolis. So naturally, mysteries and mostly stigma tend brew because there are so many things unknown. Many first time visitors inside the base are remarkably underwhelmed because the base doesn’t quite live up to their imaginations.

Most people only see buildings built in various periods, and this is a part of a memory, but the buildings and the places are only empty shells once USFK move out of Yongsan Garrison. The project is interested in archiving the “soft memories”: human stories and interactions of people who spent time inside the base.

Yongsan Legacy began because we found many layers of Korea that are locked up inside the base; Stories that are not buried by modern steel and glass developments or under luxury-branded coats and dresses of Koreans today. For outsiders, Yongsan Garrison offers an opportunity to see the remarkable progress that Koreans have made since the Japanese Colonial times, and for Korean nationals, the base provides a chance to pause and reflect on their past and appreciate the present day.

The story of Yongsan Garrison does not stop at the boundaries of the base; its influence and connection reach well beyond the adjacent neighborhoods and the country. I wish people remember that there were people worked and lived on Yongsan Garrison. To me, people who passed through Yongsan Garrison over the last 70 years are the most precious assets of Yongsan Garrison. Since it is an American base, people will assume that I’m talking about 2.5 million Americans veterans who went through the base. But , in fact, about 60-70% of the people who work inside the base are Koreans and KATSUSA’s. And there were thousands of family members of the soldiers who spent time on the base doing shopping, going to church and going to school on the base. But the most people who benefited from those people are Koreans who lived in and around Yongsan Garrison and families and friends who are appreciative and naturally curious about this “beautiful country.”

Why do we need Yongsan Legacy Podcast?

Yongsan Legacy project is currently website-based community/crowd sourcing project. We have a fully customized website for the project linked to Facebook and Instagram designed specifically seek out those individuals who have served and lived on the base. From the beginning of the project, the team felt strongly about having offline meetings to better understand the community and individuals who support this project.

We have conducted more than 100 personal interviews and organized 5 open-to-public lectures by individuals who wanted share their stories related to Yongsan Garrison. After having the five talks, it was clear that not many people were eager to stand in front of people. And the team wanted to make these presentations more fun and engaging. And considering the bulk of our core supporters are located in the States, we had to look for a format that can be easily accessible for those people. The team liked that podcast can be accessible anywhere in the world, and it can be recorded anywhere. And podcasts can be quite entertaining and engaging more than conventional oral history audio recordings. Plus, a professional sound engineer / podcast producer recently joining our team gave all the reason for Yongsan Legacy to start a crowdfunding project for the Yongsan Legacy Podcast project.

Who is John Nowell?

Yongsan Legacy Podcast is a series of podcast of interviews and monologues by John Nowell. His connection with the U.S. Army Base Yongsan Garrison began in 1965 when he worked for the 7th Infrantry Division, 199 Personal Services Co. until he retired as the Public Affairs Officer of US Army Yongsan Garrison. He created special bonds and relationships within and outside the base with both Americans and Koreans.

He joined the team in April as our own Chief Communications Officer, and he’s been putting his skills and connections to good use. One of his skills that we haven’t fully realized until yet is his long standing expertise as a host and MC for events and broadcasting formats. He appeared on numerous TV programs and movies in Korea, and he also MC’ed many high profile events in Korea. His charming and witty character will be perfect for bringing out the best of each guest. 

Why should you back this project?

This project will allow many people to come forward and share their own stories and memories about Yongsan Garrison. The team firmly believes that in order for people to remember and wanting to learn about Yongsan Garrison, the stories must be entertaining and fun. The writers and producers of the podcast will do their best to make each episode entertaining, educational, heart-warming and, most importantly, fact-checked. We have now over 10 terabytes of photos, maps, and stories about Yongsan Garrison; however, we feel that people’s voices and hand gestures cannot be captured in the data. The Yongsan Legacy Podcasts and Videos will be the best format to capture the stories and memories of those people who are still alive. With your help, we can start interview and produce professional quality podcasts and videos for the future generations.

Our Plan and Commitment for The Podcast

The team truly believes that Podcast will open new doors for people who would like to share their experiences and stories about Yongsan Garrison. We know this from hosting many different formats to efficiently archive and share people's stories since 2013. More importantly, we are trying to make sharing and archiving fun for the people who are interested in learning about Yongsan Garrison. We are committed to produce the best quality podcasts that will represent the diverse community of Yongsan Garrison.

By mid-September, the team will produce one or more pilot episodes to demonstrate how Yongsan Legacy Podcast can make military base history and people stories entertaining. 

Once the campaign finishes in October, the team will start recording episodes as many episodes as the funding permits. Base on our estimate, it costs about $300 to produce an episode plus perks; that translates to about 10 episodes if our campaign is successful. 

What you get!

$5 Thank You Note / Your name will be mentioned in Yongsan Legacy Podcast website with a personalized Thank You note from our producers.

$10 Social Media Shout-out / The producers will tag you in a personalized message on one of our Yongsan Legacy social media channels / Social Media Shout-out

$25 Your Name in the credits / Your name will be mentioned as a special thanks in the credits of a Yongsan Legacy episode! 

$50 Early Download / Receive a pre-release download of Yongsan Legacy Podcast before anyone else!

$75 Magnet Bumper Sticker / High-quality Yongsan Legacy magnet bumper sticker that will not leave goo on your car /

$100 Yongsan Legacy T-shirt / Receive a custom-designed Yongsan Legacy T-shirt

$100 Yongsan Legacy Baseball Cap / Receive a custom-designed Yongsan Legacy Baseball Cap

$300 Short Story Corner/ Have your story related to Yongsan Garrison and Yongsan read during one of the episodes. And all the perks listed above.

$500 Guest on an Episode / Be a guest on an episode or designate a person whom you think Yongsan Legacy should interview as a part of Yongsan Legacy project. And all the perks listed above.

$1000 Episode Sponsor / Collaborate with the team to produce one of the episodes from choosing a topic to selecting background music of your choice. And all the perks listed above.

$2000 or more Platinum Sponsor / Put Yongsan Legacy Podcast on the road! John Nowell will travel to record an episode to talk about your own experience with Yongsan Garrison and beyond. And all the perks listed above.

For more information

Please contact, yongsanglegacy@gmail.com

And you can check our activities and access open source database on www.yongsanlegacy.org.

And please share Yongsan Legacy through www.facebook.com/yongsanlegacy and #yongsanlegacy on Instagram.

Thank you for your support!

Yongsan Legacy Podcast Team

John Nowell, Daniel Oh, Coco Cugat, Jiyoung Yeom

But the most people who benefited from those people are Koreans who lived in and around Yongsan Garrison and families and friends who are appreciative and naturally curious about this “beautiful country.”Why do we need Yongsan Legacy Podcast?Yongsan Legacy project is currently website-based community/crowd sourcing project. We have a fully customized website for the project linked to Facebook and Instagram designed specifically seek out those individuals who have served and lived on the base. From the beginning of the project, the team felt strongly about having offline meetings to better understand the community and individuals who support this project.We have conducted more than 100 personal interviews and organized 5 open-to-public lectures by individuals who wanted share their stories related to Yongsan Garrison. After having the five talks, it was clear that not many people were eager to stand in front of people. And the team wanted to make these presentations more fun and engaging. And considering the bulk of our core supporters are located in the States, we had to look for a format that can be easily accessible for those people. The team liked that podcast can be accessible anywhere in the world, and it can be recorded anywhere. And podcasts can be quite entertaining and engaging more than conventional oral history audio recordings. Plus, a professional sound engineer / podcast producer recently joining our team gave all the reason for Yongsan Legacy to start a crowdfunding project for the Yongsan Legacy Podcast project.Who is John Nowell?Yongsan Legacy Podcast is a series of podcast of interviews and monologues by John Nowell. His connection with the U.S. Army Base Yongsan Garrison began in 1965 when he worked for the 7th Infrantry Division, 199 Personal Services Co. until he retired as the Public Affairs Officer of US Army Yongsan Garrison. He created special bonds and relationships within and outside the base with both Americans and Koreans.He joined the team in April as our own Chief Communications Officer, and he’s been putting his skills and connections to good use. One of his skills that we haven’t fully realized until yet is his long standing expertise as a host and MC for events and broadcasting formats. He appeared on numerous TV programs and movies in Korea, and he also MC’ed many high profile events in Korea. His charming and witty character will be perfect for bringing out the best of each guest. Why should you back this project?This project will allow many people to come forward and share their own stories and memories about Yongsan Garrison. The team firmly believes that in order for people to remember and wanting to learn about Yongsan Garrison, the stories must be entertaining and fun. The writers and producers of the podcast will do their best to make each episode entertaining, educational, heart-warming and, most importantly, fact-checked. We have now over 10 terabytes of photos, maps, and stories about Yongsan Garrison; however, we feel that people’s voices and hand gestures cannot be captured in the data. The Yongsan Legacy Podcasts and Videos will be the best format to capture the stories and memories of those people who are still alive. With your help, we can start interview and produce professional quality podcasts and videos for the future generations.Our Plan and Commitment for The PodcastThe team truly believes that Podcast will open new doors for people who would like to share their experiences and stories about Yongsan Garrison. We know this from hosting many different formats to efficiently archive and share people's stories since 2013. More importantly, we are trying to make sharing and archiving fun for the people who are interested in learning about Yongsan Garrison. We are committed to produce the best quality podcasts that will represent the diverse community of Yongsan Garrison.By mid-September, the team will produce one or more pilot episodes to demonstrate how Yongsan Legacy Podcast can make military base history and people stories entertaining. Once the campaign finishes in October, the team will start recording episodes as many episodes as the funding permits. Base on our estimate, it costs about $300 to produce an episode plus perks; that translates to about 10 episodes if our campaign is successful. What you get!$5 Thank You Note / Your name will be mentioned in Yongsan Legacy Podcast website with a personalized Thank You note from our producers.$10 Social Media Shout-out / The producers will tag you in a personalized message on one of our Yongsan Legacy social media channels / Social Media Shout-out$25 Your Name in the credits / Your name will be mentioned as a special thanks in the credits of a Yongsan Legacy episode! $50 Early Download / Receive a pre-release download of Yongsan Legacy Podcast before anyone else!$75 Magnet Bumper Sticker / High-quality Yongsan Legacy magnet bumper sticker that will not leave goo on your car /$100 Yongsan Legacy T-shirt / Receive a custom-designed Yongsan Legacy T-shirt$100 Yongsan Legacy Baseball Cap / Receive a custom-designed Yongsan Legacy Baseball Cap$300 Short Story Corner/ Have your story related to Yongsan Garrison and Yongsan read during one of the episodes. And all the perks listed above.$500 Guest on an Episode / Be a guest on an episode or designate a person whom you think Yongsan Legacy should interview as a part of Yongsan Legacy project. And all the perks listed above.$1000 Episode Sponsor / Collaborate with the team to produce one of the episodes from choosing a topic to selecting background music of your choice. And all the perks listed above.$2000 or more Platinum Sponsor / Put Yongsan Legacy Podcast on the road! John Nowell will travel to record an episode to talk about your own experience with Yongsan Garrison and beyond. And all the perks listed above.For more informationPlease contact, yongsanglegacy@gmail.comAnd you can check our activities and access open source database on www.yongsanlegacy.org.And please share Yongsan Legacy through www.facebook.com/yongsanlegacy and #yongsanlegacy on Instagram.Thank you for your support!Yongsan Legacy Podcast TeamJohn Nowell, Daniel Oh, Coco Cugat, Jiyoung Yeom

story:
Infringement

The Infringement Festival is a vital part of Buffalo's art culture, and a summer tradition that's been going strong for 14 years. We have acts that cover theater, music, art, dance, spoken word, film, and even some artists that defy genre categorizations altogether.  All proceeds---cover charges, pass-the-hat donations---go directly to the artists, with the bare minimum set aside to cover technical expenses. We need your financial help to produce the festival program and cover technical expenses.

Can you support us in this endeavor? You'll be able to say that you directly support the arts in Buffalo.

What We Need & What You Get

We publish a large insert in the Public, one of the local "alternative" weeklies, as well as ads in other publications. We also rent PA and stage gear for a limited number of venues.

  • We still need about $2000, on top of what we've raised through fundraiser concerts.
  • We offer festival t-shirts and stickers/decals as rewards for funding us.
  • Every little bit counts. We've never fallen short, and with your help, 2017 will be no different.

Impact

We are the largest (but not the only) festival of our kind. Although the original Infringement Festival was started and is still run in Montreal, QC by one of the original founders, Buffalo's festival is the only one that has expanded to 11 days and 400+ artists.

Your donation supports artists. It allows for works to be presented both in interesting, unique spaces and by artists who do not normally get a lot of exposure. We cover a range of aesthetics, experience-levels, and we allow artists to get out of their comfort zones and present original, new, and challenging work.

Your donation also supports audiences. Without the people who come out to shows, this festival would not continue to exist.

Risks & Challenges

There is always the risk of a budgetary shortfall, or that some venue will suddenly close. Our organizer committee is our biggest strength. Collectively, we have 100+ years of experience making this thing a reality. We are also constantly bringing in new people to help us figure out how to make things happen.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that you may not be able to help us financially. Here's how you can help us:

  • Share our campaign with your networks.
  • Volunteer to help at the festival or in the weeks leading up to it. We'll find something for you to do.
  • Submit a performance/screening/etc. proposal (next year).
  • Come out and support us. Attend!

We cannot do this without you! Thank you so very much.

story:
History Chip's Story

My name is Jean McGavin, the founder of History Chip. My story spans my life as a mother, a business owner, artist and historian. Bolstering my own story is a childhood love of the wonder and exoticism available to each of us from the hearing of a simple story. 

So, I built History Chip to provide the wonderful stories of ordinary folks in a fully searchable platform. History Chip's mission is to include everyone's stories into the history of our world - the stories of farmers, and nomads and immigrants and people in developing countries. Stories about women and minorities and garbage collectors and seamstresses and commuters - everyone’s stories - and to make them integral parts of our history. This is not simply to be inclusive but most importantly to make our history more truthful and more wonderful. Without the stories of huge swaths of people, you just don’t have a complete truth. If our history leaves out the stories of women or men or people of color or Catholics or Australians or Chileans, the story is just not complete.

In short, by contributing to our campaign, you are helping to rewrite history. You are helping to expand history to include the stories of the 99% of us whose stories aren’t in history books. This is only possible now because of the internet. History Chip is vital to having a full understanding of our place in a larger world, how what we do impacts others, how a changing climate affects peoples’ lives, how we can demystify differences amongst us. History Chip is inclusive, broadens our understanding of the truth and welcomes the wonderful stories of everyone.

How You Can Help History Chip

Reaching our fund raising goal of $30,000 will pay our developer and designer for the building of History Chip and will provide for some continuing development costs. If we raise beyond our goal of $30,000, any additional funds will be invested into further development of the project - to monitor the site, to maintain the site, to continue to develop and expand History Chip and to attend to issues as they arise. Monetizing History Chip as a free service, we will have minimal ads on the site, which will defray costs as visitor participation expands. History Chip will also offer visitors an upgrade option without ads and some additional perks for a nominal monthly fee. We are excited that our fundraiser will get us going as we approach a sustaining income stream.

Our perks are all ones that we think are useful and might inspire you to write a story for History Chip, as well as upgrade offers for use of the site and a History Chip Wall of Fame for significant contributions.

Why History Chip?

History Chip is engaged in a campaign with a mission that will enhance truth, offer every single person on this planet the awareness that their stories have value - that their lives have value. History Chip truly is rewriting history by including the stories never before included and that is revolutionary. At History Chip we value the lived experience of every single person. At History Chip every person’s stories matter. No one is excluded. In this way, History Chip expands the truth of history.

What Makes History Chip Viable?

History Chip has been in development for a number of years, bumping up against the pitfalls and barriers and we always come up with positive results. We have spent a good while exploring the project and have become more and more convinced over time with its value and positive changes that it will provide to the world and to our historical narrative. 

Other Ways You Can Help History Chip

You may not feel that you can contribute financially right now, but there are other great ways you can support History Chip! Sharing this with your friends, asking them to support the project, writing a story and adding it to History Chip, and asking your friends to do the same will be fantastic! We need visitors, writers, friends as well as financial contributions. So, share the love! Use the Indiegogo share tools, share this with your friends on social media. If each of your friends asks each of their friends to pass this on, we will be on our way to truly making history!

Testimonials

"Congratulations on your site rebranding and best of luck on your crowdfunding event. Having contributed to your site in the past, I am grateful for the opportunity to have my stories preserved for future generations in a cultural and historical context. I hope that future researchers, academics and just plain folks might come upon contributors’ posts and come away with a better understanding of the world in which we lived and our small place in it. Thank you for that."

    —Charles Micelli

 

"History Chip is an important and awesome archive of all of us! We can gain perspective and insight about familiar events and learn about others- adding a richness to the fabric of our lives. I found myself mesmerized in the process of hearing and reading these offerings!???"

  --Mary Spalding O'Meara

 

"Dear Ms History Chip,

I've lived 8 1/2 lives of my nine so far and they have been exciting, global, and unusual. I don't usually write about myself, even though people often say I should. I think History Chip sounds like a perfect place to share some of them with people who want a picture of real life in our times..

My best,

Jack Siler"

story:
Siri makes a break to take up some space.

  Hello, I am an interior designer with experience creating private gathering spaces where people feel taken care of and at ease.  Recently I have worked on several public spaces which have really piqued my interest - The Minneapolis Institute of Arts, a boutique brow salon, women's clothing boutiques, and a non-profit pediatric dental clinic. These public space projects have opened my imagination to how I might create a public gathering space for others to use.  

I am looking to create a place where others can host, share ideas and connect.  There are many public spaces available to gather in, but they lack the warmth and thoughtful care that I want in a gathering space.  Maybe you agree, you feel that this idea could really add to the community and culture of the Twin Cities.  Maybe you’d like to gather in a casual, safe warm environment that was designed intelligently and intentionally for the purpose of bringing people together and making them feel special. If so, I am asking you to help me with the initial capital for such a space.  I do not have the resources to invest the capital to get this project off the ground, but with your help I am confident that we can make it happen and I can keep it going into the future. 

What We Need & What You Get

What I am looking for is the capital to cover the startup costs for the first 1-3 years of this project while I create the space, spread the word and organize the logistics of running a viable business. Your participation in supporting this project means that you get to use the space first when it is ready! In the first year of this project, I'll host a few (free) friends + family events. Additionally, I will organize and host several ticketed events. This first year will be my time to get the word out, to get people in the door and show off the charm and flexibility of the space.  I will use this time to inspire in others, ideas about the many ways this space can be used in for community or private events they may like to host themselves. 

Your participation will translate directly toward ticketed events.  For example, if you donate $25, you'll receive a $25 gift certificate toward a ticketed event.  If you donate thousands of dollars, we'll host your private event(s) for you (see "perks" for details).

Here are the major expenses that I am looking to cover:

  • Buildout of the kitchen and outdoor area- lighting, appliances, pizza oven, sound absorption, fixtures and working surfaces ~18K
  • Modular furniture for 49 guests (tables, seating, etc.) ~8K

The Impact

  • This project represents a chance to make a different kind of gathering place. A place for you and your community to eat, discuss, to read, to create, and celebrate together.  There are so many talented interesting people in this community who I would love to connect and bring together in a more thoughtful way- book clubs, art shows, dinners, ...This is a space for people throughout the Twin Cities to gather in, to connect over a common interest or idea.
  • This project is about the intersection of hospitality and space, a project I am uniquely suited for. I have eight years of experience working as an interior designer as well as 5 years of previous experience planning both private and public events. The skills I've cultivated situate me as the right person to make this happen.
  • The closer I get to my fundraising goal the more I am freed up to create an optimal space -rather than something that is simply good enough.   The success of this project really depends on making this space function seamlessly for others, and to my standards.

Risks & Challenges

  • I am prepared to undertake this because it is a natural confluence of many of the things that I am interested in and the skills that I have cultivated over the last two decades. It is something we do not have in our community and that I can do well.
  • The biggest challenge to this project is really the startup money. I am prepared to pursue this whether I reach my full goal or not. In that case I will continue to pursue ways to cover the expenses, but your support makes it possible for me to focus on doing this project right. Your support allows me to make the use of the space focused on community first rather than focusing on covering the space's expenses.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If this idea excites you please tell your friends, family and community about it.  Please join in spreading the word.  Thank you!
